078681859X|5.0|At the tender age of six years, Nathaniel is taken from his parents and apprenticed as a learning magician to Arthur Underwood, a minor functionary in a dark and fantastical English government. This bleak London's parliamentarians and upper crust are members of a greedy, self-serving ruling class of magicians and everyone else is disparagingly referred to as a \\"commoner\\". When Nathaniel encounters Simon Lovelace, a brutal, ruthless magician whose ambition knows no limits, Lovelace chooses to openly display his terrifying power and publicly humiliates Nathaniel while Underwood stands meekly by doing nothing to defend his young charge who has barely begun to learn the rudiments of his magical craft. Angered beyond endurance, Nathaniel decides to secretly accelerate his own learning and begins to plot his revenge against Lovelace.<br /><br />When he quietly masters one of the most difficult spells in a magician's repertoire, Nathaniel summons Bartimaeus, an ancient djinni (with a rather acerbic wit and a very dry sense of humour), and commands him to steal Lovelace's greatest treasure, The Amulet of Samarkand. Unaware that Lovelace was planning on putting the amulet to use in a treasonous coup to overthrow the government, Nathaniel finds himself trapped in a maelstrom of evil, espionage, murder and magical Royal Rumbles and is now pursued as the object of a merciless manhunt.<br /><br />Much more than a mere Harry Potter wannabe knock-off, The Amulet of Samarkand treats us not only to a blazing quick page turner but also throws in a generous helping of more adult issues such as questioning the morality of class distinctions; the development of a resistance movement to a dictatorial government clearly interested in nothing more than the perpetuation of its own comfort and rule; and power lust, greed or altruism as motives for action.<br /><br />Stroud's use of footnotes, far from being distracting is actually quite infectious. Bartimaeus, in the manner of a quietly comic George Burns, well aware of his own comedic skills, steps out of character and out of the story in the footnotes, to offer his own sotto voce observations and asides directly to the reading audience. Judiciously sprinkled throughout the novel, Stroud has kept their number and length at exactly the right level to ensure the high-speed plot is not dampened.<br /><br />The happy ending of the story is not only wonderfully satisfying but open-ended enough that we know (nay, we hope) there is more to come! A couple of the mean dudes have simply vanished into hiding (you don't suppose they'll be back, do you?). Bartimaeus has been dismissed in a cloud of misty smoke and brimstone to his own spirit world and Nathaniel clearly begins to struggle with much more adult ideas of what must be done with his new found reputation, position and rapidly advancing skills and powers.<br /><br />The Amulet of Samarkand is a delicious, fast-paced lightweight reading confection that can be recommended to readers of all ages. I'm off to find a copy of The Golem's Eye.<br /><br />Paul Weissy comic George Burns, well aware of his own comedic skills, steps out of character and out of the story in the footnotes, to offer his own sotto voce observations and asides directly to the reading audience. Judiciously sprinkled throughout the novel, Stroud has kept their number and length at exactly the right level to ensure the high-speed plot is not dampened. <br /> <br />The happy ending of the story is not only wonderfully satisfying but open-ended enough that we know (nay, we hope) there is more to come! A couple of the mean dudes have simply vanished into hiding (you don't suppose they'll be back, do you?). Bartimaeus has been dismissed in a cloud of misty smoke and brimstone to his own spirit world and Nathaniel clearly begins to struggle with much more adult ideas of what must be done with his new found reputation, position and rapidly advancing skills and powers. <br /> <br />The Amulet of Samarkand is a delicious, fast-paced lightweight reading confection that can be recommended to readers of all ages. I'm off to find a copy of The Golem's Eye. <br /> <br />Paul Weiss
0375830995|4.0|Ed Kennedy is a 19 year-old cab driver living in Australia who has nothing going for him.  His mother hates him, his job sucks, his friends are just like him, and he's in love with his best friend, who is always with someone else.  \\"His best friend says, 'It's Just Ed,' Just Ed.\\"  Ed basically has no meaning in life, until, he stops a bank robbery.  He soon starts to receive playing cards in the mail with addresses on them and other riddles.  When he follows the cards he finds people that he must help.  Whether they need a helping hand, or a gun pointed to their head, Ed is there to help.  But what happens when he finishes all of these missions?  This is a great mystery that holds something deeper on the inside.  The author does a great job of keeping this book exciting and fast-paced.  I recommend this book to anyone.

B00005Q4CS|5.0|Fasten your seatbelt and leave the popcorn in the cupboard, this movie moves through your senses like a runaway freight train. The cinematography and musical score act like a claw hammer pounding away at your psyche bringing you into the lives of ordinary people caught up in the \\"American Dream,\\" the dream that leaves so many behind without hope, without love, without faith. Brutally frank in its depiction of taking the shortcut to our dreams, it depicts addiction, both legal and illegal, and its short and long term effects. The final prenatal position scenes wrench your guts out and leave you knowing that you have witnessed cinema at its finest.
B0006HXXBA|4.0|After the stunning return to form in 2001's \\"Violent Revolution\\", I was eagerly anticipating this latest Kreator record and by and large it does the job if in a bit less effective manner. \\"Enemy Of God\\" starts off very much in the vein of their last record with the scorching title track building a head of steam that is quickly followed by a succession of solid mid-paced thrash numbers that highlight Kreator's ability to write some of the best thrash grooves in the business. <br /> <br />Nothing here is mind blowing or even that different from their previous work but it's executed perfectly and sounds just different enough to keep you interested. A big part of that different sound is a new melodic undercurrent that gives a nod to some of the newer metal bands. There's a lot more dual lead guitar riffs worked into the songs as opposed to just blazing fast solos. <br /> <br />Besides a new emphasis on more melodic passages, the other big difference between this material and their older work is the speed. The songs here never achieve the vicious pace of classic albums like \\"Extreme Aggression\\" or \\"Coma Of Souls\\" but you can hear hints of similar riffs in many places, just not quite as fast. To purists this may be enough to give a pass on this album but it would be shame to dismiss this album just because it's not as fast as stuff they wrote fifteen years ago. <br /> <br />\\"Enemy Of God\\" is definitely a worthy addition to the Kreator catalog, especially in light of some of the junk they were putting out in the late nineties, but it's not quite as good as \\"Violent Revolution\\". Even though the songs here are dealt from the same deck stylistically, I can't help but get the feeling \\"Violent Revolution\\" has the better hand in the form of faster, more traditional Kreator fare. That disc is pretty much solid from start to finish whereas \\"Enemy Of God\\" has relies a bit too much on melody versus the straight out thrash Kreator is famous for delivering in spades. <br /> <br />Check out more reviews at ohboydestroy.
0553260111|4.0|I was propelled to read this book after watching the movie- and I decided to read the first of three Bourne books.  It took four days to read this book during a family vacation.  Needless to say, the book was hard to put down.  The story is captivating, slowly (although sometimes too slowly) revealing to the reader the twists and turns in the plot.  The main character is a fascinating character, slowly coming to life in the book through his own self-realization.  This was an interesting way to reveal a main character.  Though the character and his circumstances are seemingly beyond the realm of possibility, the plot of the book is amazing, tying everything together resulting in pleasurable reading.<br /><br />On a negative note- at times the book goes slow for my taste.  The strength of this book is not in the author's writing style, but in his ability to tell a suspenseful story.  At times the book tries to get too cute and too clever concerning the writing.  This author will never win any Pulitzers, and I don't believe he should even try.  Also, I realize that there probably needs to be a girl for the main character- but why does she and her interaction with the main character have to be both boring and unbelievable?  Outside of these things the book was thoroughly enjoyable.  I plan on reading the two following installments in the Bourne series.  In a closing note, the movie is good- but hardly resembles the book.  I think it would be too difficult to make a good movie by sticking closely to the book, but I was a little bit disappointed that there were few resemblances.
B000F1IQMS|4.0|I think movies that delve into modern history to remind us what has happened and why events such as these shouldn't ever be lost to memory have to be my favorite. Munich is this type of film. Though named for the events that happened in 1972 Olympic Games, Munich follows not only what happened to the Israeli athletes but the reciprocation as well. Essentially, it turns into one man's story to fight for a country he believes in as a Jew and an Israeli, yet finds himself horrified by what he and his comrades have done and what they had done to them.<br /><br />What hit me immediately about this film was the attempt Steven Spielberg made to try and keep his film culturally neutral. Though I think he failed, he did make an effort, which I have to appreciate as someone who has very little tolerance for racism. Movies such as this can create a stir, especially when they are as successful as Munich was, and creating a deeper sense of hatred between the two opposing cultures in this movie is something that definitely would have ruined the experience for me. So, though at times he slipped a little, Steven Spielberg did a great job at putting a human in all the roles, and not making monsters out of a culture we don't understand.<br /><br />That leads me to the film itself, which was done to perfection. Steven Spielberg still is the greatest director out there, and shows that yet again with Munich. This is one tense film, starting early and only occasionally giving us breathers. Spielberg also did a lot to make the characters likable, despite the fact that they were political assassins. This movie plays out in stages, starting of course with the actual taking of the hostages in Munich, moving into the political battles of how best to get revenge for the massacre, and finally the undertaking of that revenge. The first two steps pass by rather quickly, and the action and suspense take over in the third step. Here is where the story of Avner begins to unfold, as he leads a group of five assassins--including Avner--who are charged by Golda Mier, the Israeli Prime Minister, to take out the eleven Palestinians who planned the Munich massacre. But as the group begins killing, and they become more and more accustomed to it, things begin to turn bad. Avner must find a way to deal with the hardships of being a family man and an assassin, while also keeping his team together.<br /><br />Though I didn't give this a perfect rating, I still highly recommend this movie to everyone. Steven Spielberg takes his liberties, but all directors do in the end, and this movie never really attempts to be completely truthful. What it does attempt is a possible explanation of closely guarded historical events. And even if you aren't interested in learning, this is still a great action movie filled with lots of suspense.oup of five assassins--including Avner--who are charged by Golda Mier, the Israeli Prime Minister, to take out the eleven Palestinians who planned the Munich massacre. B000E6UK5K|5.0|Gilmour proves that he doesn't need his bandmates to produce a fantastic album yet again with \\"On An Island\\". This album sounds like a new Floyd album. David Gilmour, unmoving to the current trends, instead sticks with the sound of classic Pink Floyd albums, enhancing them with his tremendous abilities on the guitar, piano, sax, vocals, etc. Gilmour shows with this album that despite the general credit going to Roger Waters, Gilmour was just as much the genius behind Pink Floyd as Roger Waters was. Though Pink Floyd may be gone, Gilmour has released his first solo album in 18 years and it certainly holds up to old Pink Floyd albums while holding up to Gilmour's previous solo works as well. <br /> <br />1. \\"Castellorizon\\" - Awesome guitar solo instrumental track along with a lot of orchestral arrangements involved with it. David Gilmour proves even in 2006 he can play the guitar just as well as in 1976. *****/***** <br /> <br />2. \\"On An Island\\" - Gilmour's guitar ability really stands out on it and it sounds really good. I'd place the guitar parts along the lines of A Momentary Lapse Of Reason and the vocal parts around Meddle. *****/***** <br /> <br />3. \\"The Blue\\" - Very Meddle sounding song and reminds me somewhat of \\"Fat Old Sun\\" from Atom Heart Mother. ****/***** <br /> <br />4. \\"Take A Breath\\" - Definitely place this with The Wall. It has similar arrangements to a lot of songs on that album. It's good though. *****/***** <br /> <br />5. \\"Red Sky At Night\\" - Shortest track on the album, but it's not filler. Gilmour shows off his brilliant saxophone playing in a haunting track. This really reminds me of the heavily sax dominated Dark Side Of The Moon. *****/***** <br /> <br />6. \\"This Heaven\\" - An odder sounding track compared to the others. Probably the least Pink Floyd song on the album yet but I like it. It sounds more bluesy than most Floyd or rock songs in general. ****/***** <br /> <br />7. \\"Then I Close My Eyes\\" - A very harmonic, melodic instrumental track. Unfortunately, it lacks a certain element the other songs had. It sounds a lot like The Division Bell. It sounds nice but it just doesn't have much of a drive to it. ***/***** <br /> <br />8. \\"Smile\\" - Another song that reminds me of \\"Fat Old Sun\\" and some of the Meddle tracks like \\"A Pillow Of Winds\\". It suffers from the same lack of energy that \\"Then I Close My Eyes\\" had yet it manages to make up for it better than that song with the other elements of it. ***1/2/***** <br /> <br />9. \\"A Pocketful Of Stones\\" - Another Meddle sounding track but with a lot more piano to it. A nice song with nice piano playing. Slowly, the song increases in heaviness and the lyrics become increasingly darker. Finally, around the five minute mark, Gilmour cuts in with a dark, depressing guitar solo that fits the song perfectly and leaves nothing more to be desired from what is a beautiful solo that finishes out the song. *****/***** <br /> <br />10. \\"Where We Start\\" - This one sounds like a mix of Meddle and Wish You Were Here. A slow, melodic song, it works well enough I suppose for the album closer though I feel that \\"A Pocketful Of Stones\\" would've worked better. ****/***** <br /> <br />Gilmour brings to the table a fantastic mix of every era of Pink Floyd but in particular combines the sounds of \\"Meddle\\", \\"A Momentary Lapse Of Reason\\", and \\"Wish You Were Here\\" to create a great album. Though Pink Floyd may be gone, David Gilmour is here with an album that will please most fans of Floyd and continues the traditions begun by his old band.

B00005JOVN|4.0|\\"Poseidon\\" is one of those movies where character development, human inspiration, thought provoking themes, social commentary, or anything resembling an argument or point are all summarily ignored in favor of entertainment and a more visceral movie going experience.  Viewers can leave their brains at the door - they won't be needed here.  This isn't necessarily a bad thing, as Poseidon definitely achieves what it sets out to.  The audience will be enthralled with the amazing effects and entertained by the story of Macguyver style survival.  While this isn't great story telling, it is great movie making, and is worth the price of admission.<br /><br />The basic story of Poseidon is a silly as it is simple.  A huge wall of water crashes over a luxury ship while out at sea, tipping the massive boat over and submerging all the hapless inhabitants.  A small group of people ignore the pleas of the captain to remain in a sealed off room and await rescue.  Realizing the boat is going to sink soon, they search for a way out of the ship by climbing through the now upside down vessel.  Waves of this size don't actually occur anywhere in the open sea, as waves generally only exist in shallow areas or directly on shorelines, but that doesn't really matter.  The reasoning behind the movie is secondary to the action and effects, which are in abundant supply.  It's really unfair to compare the effects of this movie to the original \\"Poseidon Adventure\\", which was filmed over 30 years prior, but honestly this remake is a lot more believable than the first film.  In the original, it was quite obvious that people were voluntarily throwing themselves sideways while the camera tilted at an angle - showcased by the fact that none of the chairs fell from the ceiling.  No such suspension of disbelief occurs in this film, where quite a deal of effort has been expended to convince the viewer that a ship is in fact turning upside down.  Barring the very beginning of the movie, in which everything has a far too bright look and it's obvious some sort of green screen is being utilized, the effects used throughout the film are on par with those seen in recent special effects extravaganzas such as the Lord of the Rings series or the new remake of King Kong.  One particular effect of note occurs when a giant engine plunges through an upside down ceiling, unleashing a huge stream of fuel which soon catches on fire.  A superbly done giant pillar or flame streams endlessly downward, seemingly preventing passage by the intrepid group of survivors bent on escaping the ship.<br /><br />There is really only one direct translation of character from the original, and that is the character of the little boy who has befriended the various crew members and has a working knowledge of the boat's layout.  Everyone else is at least slightly different from the original characters.  Kurt Russell plays a character based on Gene Hackman's role in the original.  While Kurt delivers his lines in a much different style, it's easy to see why he was cast as this particular character, as Hackman and Russell look almost identical in close up shots and have very similar mannerisms.  The characters presented are all very stereotypical of our age.  There is a young couple who obviously cannot die as they are in love, a sternly disapproving father who has to show everyone how much he is willing to sacrifice for his family, a selfish man who will of course realize the error of his ways and become a more well rounded individual, a love-lorn man who wants to kill himself, and then the obligatory cannon fodder characters who will be offed quite quickly by the sinking ship.  Thankfully, they are all less annoying the characters in the original film.  During the first movie, it was hard not to root for the bleak cold depths of the oceanic deep to just get it over with and kill the lady who wouldn't quit sobbing uncontrollably and hold the team back, or the woman who would just not stop trying totell her husband to go on without her.  In the new version the viewer will never be so annoyed as to actually wish the death of any particular character.<br /><br />While lacking any kind of deep storytelling or characterization, Poseidon is a fun adventure, and worth at least viewing once.to tell her husband to go on without her.  In the new version the viewer will never be so annoyed as to actually wish the death of any particular character. <br /> <br />While lacking any kind of deep storytelling or characterization, Poseidon is a fun adventure, and worth at least viewing once.

B00005JOVN|4.0|I'm a big fan of disaster movies.  I also recently went on a cruise.  And I'm not all that fond of water.  So it was inevitable that I would see Poseidon, a movie that must be witnessed on the big screen for the full effect.<br /><br />Everyone knows the story by now: Poseidon, a massive cruise liner, flips over when a \\"rogue wave\\" strikes during a New Year's Eve celebration.  Just about every passenger is gathered in the grand ballroom, although the youngsters are also celebrating in one of the (invariably many) nightclubs on the ship.  And just like that, their world is literally turned upside down.<br /><br />Our hero is the professional gambler, Dylan Johns (Josh Lucas).  Rugged, shifty, and a little too smooth for his own good, Dylan is an ex-Navy man who lost his moral center.  He finally meets a woman seemingly immune to his charms in the form of Maggie James (Jacinda Barrett) and her son Conor (Jimmy Bennett).  What's a lovable rogue to do?<br /><br />One of those rich folks that Dylan separates from their money is Robert Ramsey (Kurt Russell), a former New York City mayor and ex-fireman.  His daughter Jennifer (Emmy Rossum) struggles for her independence with her boyfriend Christian (Mike Vogel). There's also the lovelorn Richard Nelson (Richard Dreyfuss) who is considering killing himself, and the secret couple of Marco Valentin (Freddy Rodriguez) who smuggles aboard Elena Gonzalez (Mia Maestro). And how could we forget one-note Lucky Larry (Kevin Dillon)!<br /><br />While the ship's captain, Michael Bradford (Andre Braugher) advises that everyone stay in the ballroom, Dylan has other plans.  He leads Maggie, Conor, Robert, Richard, and Marco to find his daughter in the nightclub.  Facing their own struggles to survive in the nightclub are Jennifer, Christian, Elena and yes...Lucky Larry.<br /><br />I don't remember the original Poseidon Adventure very well, but it was a very detached experience, much less horror and much more of a character study.  Fortunately, director Wolfgang Petersen isn't interested in showing how good an actor can mime hysterics.  Instead, he goes for the throat; this is a disaster film and it looks like it: dead bodies float everywhere.  When the ship flips, everything flips with it, and we can never forget that our protagonists are upside-down because every sign, door, and table is the wrong way.  And then there's the water.<br /><br />Gurgling, growling, snaking through shafts, suffused with flames; water has never been so terrifying.  The survivors must swim through a conflagration, in the dark, through a nettle of wires, past floating dead bodies, and at one point, hold their breath to the breaking point.  It is horrible.  It is undoubtedly realistic.  It is a disaster movie with a capital D.<br /><br />Throughout, there are little bits of humor that help relieve the tension.  I mean, there's a guy named Lucky Larry for crying out loud!  Conversely, Poseidon is deadly serious about the plight of its characters, and the survivors must make a host of moral choices that force us to ask: faced with survival or death, would we make the same decisions and sacrifices?<br /><br />Disaster movies are in a particular quandary these days.  It's no longer sufficient to pretend that we're watching a make believe event that can happen to fictional people.  Always lurking in the back of our minds is the possibility that whatever disaster we're witnessing could happen to us...or happened recently.  When is a movie about a disaster appropriate?<br /><br />The answer is that there is no appropriate timing for a film.  I think releasing Poseidon on May Day was an inspired choice.  It's our reaction to it that moviegoers must ultimately decide for themselves.  If the film disturbs you...then perhaps that was the point.<br /><br />If you're ready for a wild ride, if you've ever been afraid of water, or if you always wondered what nature thinks of big floating cities in her oceans...see Poseidon.dy. It's our reaction to it that moviegoers must ultimately decide for themselves. B000EWBNMS|5.0|I'm hooked on this show, and its easily one of my favories. I'm very happy the 1st season will be available on DVD soon.
0618477942|5.0|This is a sharp, literate, excruciating, and mature piece of autobiography, which should with any justice nudge Alison Bechdel from cult favorite to widespread critical recognition.   <br /> <br />Her always appealing and humane art is given emotional depth and shadow with a layer of ink wash, which Houghton Mifflin has thankfully payed out to print in faded royal blue. <br /> <br />In terms of content, Bechdel ably and appropriately includes themes from Proust, Joyce, Homer, and F.Scott Fitzgerald as she strip-mines the contorted relationship between her younger self and her English teacher father.   <br /> <br />This is a work of real emotional honesty, paired with a professional execution.  It's also a welcome change from the relentless brand of masculine self-loathing dished out by R.Crumb and Harvey Pekar, and more mature than the delicate, achingly self-aware recent works by Craig Thompson.   <br /> <br />The overall quality and insight of the work brings it beyond being just a female, feminist, or queer genre piece (all of which Bechdel has done with great aplomb in the past);  with any luck it should make itself felt across the demographic bar chart.

B0009IW8IK|4.0|The Swedes clearly figured out what worked well on their first album and decided to work with their strengths. Gone are all the little transitional instrumentation (violin, cello, female vocals) and overkill of experimentation. What we're left with is melodic death metal, filled with hooks and leads along with a more fine tuned aggression. They still run with acoustic interludes and an almost folk influence on occasions, yet the transitions are far better than on their debut album.  <br /> <br />The band hadn't yet settled on a line-up, with vocalist Anders Friden yet to join the fray. In fact, only Jesper Stromblad is still with the band today (2006) and he didn't play on the debut. So it's not completely surprising that Subterranean period In Flames is nothing like the albums released since the year 2000. Vocalist Henrik is great (also in Dawn) and Daniel's drumming is awesome, but it's once again the dual guitars of Jesper and Glenn that make this EP so good. Check out \\"Stand Ablaze\\" or \\"Subterranean\\" for exhibitions of brilliant melodic musicianship.  <br /> <br />In Flames are reaching their peak with Subterranean, both as musicians and as songwriters. With only 5 tracks and a running time of just over 20 minutes, it was an excellent teaser for the bands next couple of full length albums that would be the pinnacle of their career. Regain's re-mastered edition of this album released in 2004 has a far superior sound and is well worth purchasing, even for the fans that own the Wrong Again Records CD from the mid nineties, particularly for the bonus tracks and covers that come included.  <br /> <br />Overall, a step up in class for In Flames and a fine example of the Gothenburg sound that has been completely bombarded with clones for years since its release.

B0001MDQ2G|5.0|Orphaned Land makes me proud to be a metal fan! With the complete lack of respect that the metal scene in general has to face due to a complete lack of understanding and narrow-mindedness, it can sometimes be difficult to admit that you think Carcass' \\"Necroticism\\" album is one of the best things you've ever heard. It's hard not to feel just a little apprehensive about letting your workmates know that your favourite band is My Dying Bride, or that Robbie Williams' latest album is crap compared to the latest Behemoth masterpiece. It's bands like Orphaned Land that release music of such a high quality and with a level of integrity and class that annihilate any doubts I have about my chosen path, and make me feel just a little perturbed that the majority of society are too narrow-minded to ever experience it.     It's been 7 years since the bands last studio album and I'm not completely sure whether this is due to environmental factors (they come from Israel) or whether the band has simply spent the 7 years preparing the album. I wouldn't at all be surprised if the latter turned out to be correct, since \\"Mabool\\" (which translates as \\"flood\\") is a truly monumental album, pieced together with such care and depth that I can't begin to imagine how much time and effort has gone into it.    After really enjoying \\"Sahara\\" back in the early 90s as well as its follow-up a year later, I was always hoping the band would release another studio album. If they did, I expected it would be a fine melodic death album with a major injection of Arabic influence. I expected it would show moments of intimacy and outbursts of powerful emotion and passion. I even expected the intense creativity that makes up this epic, but what I never expected was a religious theme based album that displays a level of musicianship and skilfully crafted pieces of work that has left me speechless. Well...almost.    Yes, you heard right. This album tells the story of the flood from the bible. Now, I find it difficult to not let my personal feelings about religion get in the way when I listen to Christian metal, but no-one should let that get in the way of listening to \\"Mabool\\". There is no preaching of any sort, this is purely story telling.    There are exquisite female vocals, excellent clean and death metal male vocals, incredible guitar solos, perfectly placed keyboards and samples, acoustic interludes, and crushing riffs. The range of emotions that Orphaned Land integrate to express their biblical story are just astounding and never sound contrived or overwhelming.    I find myself finishing reviews too often lately with \\"this album is not for everyone\\", but damn it, this one is! If you have even the slightest interest in heavy music, then there's no excuse not to check this out. It's album of the year and I'm proud to be a metal fan!

B000001C6M|5.0|Slayer's importance to extreme metal in general can never be underestimated. When metal was at its most groundbreaking and exciting peak, these U.S. youngsters were the driving force (along with another young American band you may have heard of called Metallica), releasing several hugely influential albums along the way. \\"Show No Mercy\\" is merely the beginning of this journey, but filled with significance for more than this reason alone. If one looks at where metal was at the time of its release (1983), it's no wonder Slayer caused such a stir. The obvious influences are Venom, Iron Maiden and Metallica. In fact, it was the latter of these three bands that influenced Slayer to play faster and more aggressive after the youths witnessed a Metallica concert in 1982. But while Venom's albums were tongue in cheek Satanic, Slayer's music, image and lyrics were as evil as music got. Tracks such as \\"Evil Has No Boundaries\\" and \\"Black Magic\\" dripped with malevolence and metal has never looked back since.    Looking at the album today after 23 years, it's surprisingly still a great listen. The band had already found their sound. It's dirtier and less produced than anything that would follow, but the trademark Slayer riffs and solos, as well as the mid paced powerful drumming is already in place. Tom Araya's vocals contained more high-pitched screaming than usual as was the trend of the day, but considering the range of his voice, it was never a bad thing. Quite a few of these tracks would be played live for many years to come including \\"Die by the Sword\\" and \\"The Antichrist\\" and I certainly see \\"Show No Mercy\\" as not simply a fine piece of nostalgia, but a bloody impressive slab of thrash metal, filled with youthful exuberance and talent. The fact that the band still today contains the same four members is proof enough of just how well these guys function together and that their vision has always been singular.    All in all, a great and entertaining debut release from a bandthat would very soon enter the realms of metal immortality.
B000F48CD8|5.0|Great album, Jack White with a full band, oh man, cool sound terrific lyrics, one of the best bands i've ever heard
B0006HXXBA|5.0|Now this is what thrash is all about! I must admit that I'd almost given up on thrash a few years ago. With more and more of my previously favourite thrash entities either disbanding (Exodus), moving away from their roots (Metallica) or releasing sub-standard albums (Megadeth), it looked like the genre was finally about to kick the bucket.    Then all of a sudden, the thrash machine has regained its momentum, and a string of excellent releases and band reformations have come about. Exodus, Sodom, Testament and now Kreator have released their best albums since the 80s and thrash is back!    \\"Enemy of God\\" is Kreator's 11th full-length studio album and comes 20 years after their debut \\"Endless Pain\\". Their earlier releases are pure classics, with 1986's \\"Pleasure to Kill\\" and 1989's Extreme Aggression\\" being the highlights. Although the band went through an uncomfortable experimental phase through the mid to late 90's, 2001's \\"Violent Revolution\\" displayed a renewed vitality and aggression that has recreated the bands glory years. \\"Enemy of God\\" continues this form and in fact raises the bar even higher.    Right from the outset, it's apparent the band means business. The title track is an awesome way to kick off the album and the sound is incredible. Ripping riffs, venomous vocals and some very impressive drumming combine in controlled violence. Mille has taken inspiration from the world's current political and religious climate, which gives him plenty of ammunition to fire and that recognizable German accent remains intact, even if he's learnt to pronounce his v's much better these days.    There are 12 tracks on \\"Enemy of God\\", all of them of suitable high Kreator quality. The difference between the old and new Kreator is that the modern phenomenon have the ability to slow it all down without displaying seams, whereas the band's minimal musicianship of the early years once hindered that sort of variety. 2005 Kreator is tight and technically superior. The nave youthfulness of their teenage years may have been long left behind, but the experience and understanding of Mille's troops more than carries the burden of expectation.    2005 has started with a bang, and if \\"Enemy of God\\" is anything to go by, we're in for one hell of a ride. Bring it on!

B000AADYYO|5.0|There are very few things that I can truly rely upon these days. Australia lost the Ashes to England in the cricket which should never have happened! Every TV show I enjoy gets cancelled! Even life itself cannot be trusted, with natural disasters ravaging the Earth all over the place this year. At least there's Opeth! Every year or two, these Swedish legends release another cracking album. No other band comes close to them for sheer consistency, at least anywhere near this quality.    It may be easy to categorise Opeth's albums into the masterpiece grouping, but it's not quite as easy to describe their music to the uninitiated. If I said death metal, you'd think of a band like Morbid Angel and they're nothing like that. If I said progressive metal, you'd probably think of a band like Evergrey and that wouldn't be fitting either. I'm going to call it atmospheric melodic progressive death metal. One thing to note about \\"Ghost Reveries\\" is that the progressive part has become much more prevalent. But that's not to say that Opeth have gone soft. This is still very much in the vein of \\"Blackwater Park\\" and \\"Deliverance\\", with death vocals mixed with clean, some crushing riffs, and a generally dark feel. Yet there's a much greater emphasis on musicality and interweaving styles, from classical music to seventies progressive rock, to magnificent mind shattering metal arrangements. It's one of those albums that the more you listen to it, the more you pick up, and the better it gets.    So much has been said about these guys already, but I really think this is their most mature album to date. I've always praised Mikael's (and Peter's) guitar work, but everyone involved has stood up on this album and displayed an immense amount of talent. Martin's drumming has always been solid, but now it is breathtaking. Mikael's vocals have improved, and considering how good he was before, that's saying something.     Every track just oozes class and all those Opeth-bashers (and there are quite a few) are seriously missing out due to some strange tall poppy syndrome. But for every jealous detractor, there are twenty Opeth worshippers anticipating new material, so I guess that's as close as I can get to a perfect world where bands get the attention and praise they truly deserve.    Highlights for me are \\"The Baying of the Hounds\\", \\"Hours of Wealth\\" and the monstrous \\"The Grand Conjuration\\", but Opeth simply can do no wrong in my books. \\"Ghost Reveries\\" is up there with \\"Still Life\\" and \\"Blackwater Park\\" as the best album from one of metal's finest acts. If you only buy around three or four albums this year, make sure this is one of them. Enough said.

B00005O3VC|4.0|As a teacher of medieval Grail literature, I have shown \\"Monty Python and the Holy Grail\\" to many generations of students -- and indeed there are a number of scenes that really do help young people understand either the medieval literary tradition or medieval history. These include not only the unforgettable \\"Bring out your dead scene,\\" which educates the fortunate modern viewer on the ubiquity of the medieval Bubonic Plague, but also the Grail Castle with its unimaginable and unaskable question, not to mention the over-the-top battle ethos that would lead to a knight's having not only his arms and legs cut off but also his head! It's hard to believe that such scenes have their medieval progenitors (though I do have to say I know of no medieval precedent for the \\"shrubbery\\" scene), but honestly they do.    More than that, however, in my book the very best scene of this film has absolutely nothing to do with the Grail or with anything medieval -- and that is the scene of the fierce rabbit. I still cannot watch this film without cracking up (as we moderns say) over the scene in which the \\"harmless little rabbit\\" attacks the Arthurian troupe. The hubris that the rabbit scene uncovers is a sadly (but hilariously) universal feature of human nature.    But even the rabbit scene hooks back into the medieval theme, as it links to an exploration of a cave with literary texts that conclude because \\"....arrgh....\\" Well, indeed, many medieval texts remain unfinished, perhaps because the authors died, more likely due to the vagaries of preservation. So Monty Python has something to say not only about history and literature but about literary history; in its very aesthetic form, this film reminds us that the standard linear narrative is not the only way of organizing a story. Many medieval stories are likewise structured either allegorically or with significant disruptions, such as this film has, that reveal that a story is something that is constructed and has its gaps and interventions.    In the \\"Age of the Da Vinci Code\\" -- another far less successful Grail story --  I'd be happy to see folks go back to Monty Python for their understanding of medieval literature and Chrisitainity. Maybe they'd learn that all enigmas are not meant to be solved; some are meant to be the topic of cleansing and cathartic laughter.

B000EHSVOG|5.0|I first saw this movie as a kid when it was released in the theaters.  As the years have gone by, I have come to appreciate the cinematic genius, the special effects, and the plots and subplots of this fine movie.  Irwin Allen was truly one of a kind.    Unfortunately Hollywood can't/won't make movies like this anymore.  Sometimes they try with flops like \\"Independence Day\\" or \\"The Day After Tommorrow, and the like but they are all pretty one-dimensional.    The Towering Inferno has EVERY thing you need for great entertainment.  The story is set around a 135 story building that hails as the tallest in the world and which has been constructed with substandard materials, especially electrical wiring.  From that starting point there are all kinds of stories that intersect and end in a high rise fire.    The overall \\"feel\\" of the movie is one that is lost these days.  There is an undeniable elegance in that runs throughout the whole film. The scenery of San Francisco as a backdrop, the sets, costumes, and music give it something that sets it apart from other films of its type.  Even the very beginning of the film with the credits is larger than life.  The rest of the movie just gets better.    It was nominated for Best Picture in 1974 and in my opinion should have won.  It ended up winning awards for techincal achievements.  However, Steve McQueen, Paul Newman, and William Holden were, in my opinion, overlooked in the acting category.  Yet they were excellent.  Fred Astaire was nominated for a supporting role as Harlee, the con man, but lost.    More than just an extremely well done movie, it is one that grabs you from the get go and thoroughly entertains in a classy, dramatic way. The special edition DVD comes with an extra disc that gives you a lot of details, theatrical trailers, an interview with Irwin Allen and more.  It is well worth it to pay a little more for this special edition.  This is one of a kind.

B0002TX4QQ|5.0|Shriver's novel suffers from a cover that cheapens its contents and a title that sounds like a Scholastic book for young readers.  Neither of these convey the literary genius of this story.  If I were crowned an editor, I would have would have titled this book Before and After That Thursday.  This is great literature manufactured as mere \\"fiction.\\"  It is as readable as anything on the bestseller list, though (no literary pretension here).<br /><br />Our narrator is Eva Khatchadourian, the mother of teenaged Kevin, who murdered seven high-school students, a cafeteria worker, and a beloved teacher in a single day (that Thursday).  Sure, the murders and the aftermath are juicy, but the story covers much more ground than the \\"incident.\\"  In a series of letters to her estranged husband, Eva examines her childhood, family relations, dating life with her husband, their marriage, the decision to have children, Kevin's troubled youth, and more.  Eva can't tell the story of Kevin, the story that made the headlines, without talking about her background and the foundation of her marriage.<br /><br />The examination of Eva's marriage and Kevin's childhood is both the strength and (slight) weakness of this novel.  Eva has no answers, and Kevin has never been open with her, nor has he ever found joy in his life, not from the time he was born.  The novel consists of Eva's meditation on every incident, every fight, every issue that shaped her family.  The weak point is that the narrator occasionally ruminates in too much societal detail, but overall, her observations are brilliant and relevant to the overall story of Kevin's life.<br /><br />The novel has one twist which any reader might see from dozens of pages away, and even though I was expecting it, it was much different than I imagined.  It still socked me in the gut, no matter how much slight foreshadowing the author offered throughout the text.<br /><br />Kevin is a fascinating psychopath, one who despises the other school killers.  He planned to show them all up with his body count, but Columbine killers Harris and Kebold \\"beat him\\" just a few weeks after his killing spree, much to Kevin's dismay.  Kevin is also especially proud because he planned his targets carefully and did not commit \\"random\\" violence.  As frustrating as Eva's relationship with Kevin is, the reader finally sees a small, small human side to her son at the end of the book.<br /><br />This is an epic tale of a marriage, motherhood, family, and a small town.  Eva's meditations on her life, her marriage, and her influence on Kevin are poignant and unforgettable.  This is a must-read novel.r school killers.  He planned to show them all up with his body count, but Columbine killers Harris and Kebold \\"beat him\\" just a few weeks after his killing spree, much to Kevin's dismay.  Kevin is also especially proud because he planned his targets carefully and did not commit \\"random\\" violence.  As frustrating as Eva's relationship with Kevin is, the reader finally sees a small, small human side to her son at the end of the book. <br /> <br />This is an epic tale of a marriage, motherhood, family, and a small town.  Eva's meditations on her life, her marriage, and her influence on Kevin are poignant and unforgettable.  This is a must-read novel.
0345350472|3.0|Not many directors can make a film that surpasses the book on which they base their work. Stanley Kubrick was a rare example of a director who accomplished the art. Ridley Scott, who directed Blade Runner, managed to do the same with Philip K. Dick's 1968 detective science fiction novel Do Androids Dream Of Electric Sheep.<br />The book narrates the story of Rick Deckard who is a bounty hunter in a post-apocalyptic San Francisco. His job is to `retire' androids who have escaped various colonies and illegally returned to earth. His hobby is to dream of owning real or artificial pets. While not quite hitting the impressive mark as a detective story, given the seeming ease with which the androids are detected and destroyed, Dick brings up quite a few serious ethical, moral and political issues. Faced with an empty existence Deckard ponders his relationship with his wife, his job and religion all the while craving artificial organisms as pets and lovers. His life and job lead to interesting questions. Is his job moral when an 'andy' can be an opera singer, negotiator, pharmacist or anything else? What is the definition of life and is it anachronistic?<br />In many respects, except for the literal storyline, the novel is reminiscent of Heinlein's seminal work, Stranger In A Strange Land. Some of the science fiction seems dated and the author's pontifications seem at odd with mainstream thought today. That, however, might say more about contemporary shortcomings than anything else.<br />The book - much like the film version - leaves a major question ambiguous and for the reader to ponder, while simultaneously leaving many hints and landmarks as clues to the answer.<br />Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep is a philosophical book that forces the reader to make a judgement call. Dead, alive or in-between the point is poignant and thought-provoking.

0064471837|5.0|I had two friends and a teacher recommend this book for me, so I decided to try it out. Sabriel is a wonderful fantasy full of magic and new creatures. A girl named Sabriel is daughter of the Abhorsen. One day when she is at school, her father appeared to her, obviously bound in death. He turns over to her the instruments of an Abhorsen. This is the moment that Sabriel has been waiting and training for, the time when she becomes Abhorsen. A Greater Dead is stirring in the Old Kingdom. Free Magic and evil are coming together. More and more dead are coming into life and invading, despite all her fathers' charms and spells. Her father is dying, so Sabriel must re-bind the dead and try to rid the Old Kingdom of this Greater Dead. This is no easy task for Sabriel, because now that she is the Abhorsen, the only one who can bind the dead, she is hated and hunted by the dead. She accumulates help from different and new people, and you will have to read the rest to find out what happens. This book was one of those books that you would read in one day, it's so good. Sabriel is the first book in the series, followed by Lirael, Abhorsen and Across the Wall. The story definitely has many interesting twists in it. Garth Nix is an absolute genius. Almost everything can tie into each other in an exciting sort of way. It is a book for everyone; it has magic, action, mystery, horror, romance and even some humor. It has animals and mythical beings and it can relate to the sort of medieval stories.<br /><br />When I first read this book, I admit I was a little frightened by the immense details in the book, but I refused to stop reading. As I read on, I found I didn't want to stop. As I was reading I went from almost crying, to white knuckled fear, to sappy, to devastating, back to sad and surprised. You will feel a huge range of emotions as you read this book. One if the things I learned from this book was how many emotions and themes you could fit into one book! I thought it impossible, but now I can try and put more feeling into my writing because I know it can be done! I have recommended this book to many of my friends and have caught them reading it. B0000009RT|5.0|In 1966, a double LP by a rock band was unheard of. And yes, it was a band. Frank Zappa gets the lion's share of the credit, being the cheif songwriter. But as the title on the cover says, it's \\"The Mothers Of Invention.\\" The first incarnation of an ever-revolving cast of musicians, all of whom had lots and lots of talent.<br /><br />As a CD, Freak Out loses some of its impact. Even though the artwork is all intact, and it's the same music, tweaked a little here and there, it's the same recordings, nonetheless. But the tactile sensation of opening a 12x12 cover into a 12x24 gate-fold onslaught is lost here. And you can tell the division of the format a little better on the LP, as the first half is  based more on traditional song structure and the second half is more experimental.<br /><br />Song titles and content vary, from social criticism (\\"Hungry Freaks\\") to songs about boy-girl relationships (\\"You Didn't Try To Call Me\\") to flat-out weirdness (\\"Who Are The Brain Police?\\"). But despite the gritty, even greasy sound, there is an innocence to it; although the band and its image are anything but. This was the most scandalous, possibly the most hated rock band in history, and they used this to their advantage. Radio stations wouldn't touch them, and every television appearance was riddled with controversy. Phone lines would flood with people who loved them, or hated them. It seems that \\"Freak Out\\" was more of a social/cultural phenomenon than a piece of music. The sleeve notes describe this in pretty vivid detail, and it would be counter-productive and a little tedious to quote it all here.<br /><br />Creative highlight: The last segment of the format, from \\"Help I'm A Rock,\\" right on through \\"The Return Of The Son Of Monster Magnet.\\" This is a suite of \\"songs,\\" for lack of a better word, more like rhythms accompanied by layer upon layer of sounds. \\"Monster Magnet\\" is the peak. It has such an elaborate spectrum of sounds and textures, it boggles the mind at first. Warning! NOT FOR PEOPLE WITH CONSERVATIVE TASTES IN MUSIC! Frank Zappa's strict anti-drug stance is cleverly hidden here, because a lot of people think you have to be stoned or tripping to come up with this. But the truth is, absolutely not; You just need some imagination to come up with it, the intellect to pull it out, and the intelligence to pull it off.<br /><br />Subsequent works showed more sophistication, but this is the true ground-breaker.WITH CONSERVATIVE TASTES IN MUSIC! Frank Zappa's strict anti-drug stance is cleverly hidden here, because a lot of people think you have to be stoned or tripping to come up with this. But the truth is, absolutely not; You just need some imagination to come up with it, the intellect to pull it out, and the intelligence to pull it off.    Subsequent works showed more sophistication, but this is the true ground-breaker.

B000F7CMRM|4.0|I thought Syriana was an excellent, ambitious, and thought-provoking film. I do agree with the other reviewers that it is a bit hard to follow, and tends to get off-track at times, but if the subject of oil or geopolitics interests you, it is well worth it. Contrary to the other reviewer, I don't see how it was over-hyped, since most people I've mentioned it to have never even heard of it.<br /><br />I thought the film had a ring of authenticity to it, especially since it is loosely based on the memoirs of former CIA agent Robert Baer. As the film goes on, you see the connection between the American and middle eastern governments, oil companies, and Islamic fundamentalists as they come together in a complex web of espionage, business deals, and terrorism. The underlying message is clear, oil makes the world go round.<br /><br />Overall, I thought Syriana was a solid political film. If you are simply looking for a decent action film that doesn't involve a lot of thinking, you will probably be disappointed, but if you don't mind thinking, Syriana is definitely enlightening. Four stars.

B00005Y46O|3.0|'Free' ushered in the 1970's as a power-rock trio in the mold of 'Cream', topped off with the powerful voice of frontman Paul Rogers, who would gleen further critical acclaim later in the decade as the voice of 'Bad Company'.  While many of 'Free's compositions are basic blues-rock, the vocal talents of Paul Rogers and the sharply punctuated guitar riffs of Paul Kossoff go a long way towards redeeming most of the selections.  Bassist Andy Fraser teams up with Rogers on most of the composing, and with drummer Simon Kirke to form a sturdy, if unspectacular rhythm section.  The band employed plenty of posturing and strutting to supplement the testosterone laced lyrics and pulsing beats, most of which is well-received as genuine by the British audiences captured here.  At the same time, the absence of stylistic diversity probably spelled out the fate of the band as a one-trick pony in the US more than anything else.  At home in England, however, where the blues was king in the mid-to-late 1960's, the band scored two additional Top Ten and one #13 hit between 1970 and 1973.  Unfortunately, none of these commercially successful tracks are performed on 'Free Live'.  <br /> <br />'Free Live' is composed of thirteen tracks recorded in January of 1970 at the Locarno Ballroom in Sunderland, England, and the 1,500 capacity Fairfield Halls Arts Center in Croydon, England in September of 1970.  In that same month, the band's only Top 40 US release, 'All Right Now', maxed out at number four.  The original vinyl closed with a studio track recorded in March of 1971, the acoustic ballad 'Get Where I Belong', and fittingly this expanded edition of 'Free Live' concludes with a more vibrant and urgent alternate take of the same track.  Sandwiched between are six additional bonus tracks from the Sunderland and Croydon performances.   <br /> <br />The producers of 'Free Live' seem keenly aware of the band's limitations, and provide two versions of three of the best tracks available.  Nothing, of course, matches up with the raw appeal of 'All Right Now', and the Croydon performance aptly demonstrates how the band's interpretation of the song evolved over the course of their touring.  It's such a stunning representation of the power rock epitomized by band's such as Led Zeppelin and Grand Funk Railroad in that same year, that it justifies the price of the disc by itself.  Two versions of 'Mr. Big', a heavy blues-rock number with a fairly catchy basic guitar hook are also offered.  Only on 'Get Where I Belong' does the band diverge significantly from the blues-rock genre, with lyrics focused on repentance and redemption (\\"Help me to repay things I have done wrong, help me find a way to get where I belong\\").  The next nearest thing to diversity is found on the second track, 'I'm a Mover', which might be better described as boogie-rock with guitar lines garnished in psychedelia.  Other than that, the remaining tracks saunter from slow to mid to fast tempo variations on the blues-rock theme.  The longest track is the plodding, bass-driven 'Moonshine', which times out at nearly nine and one-half minutes, while the shortest track is the 3:42 rendition of 'I'm a Mover'.  Both versions of 'All Right Now', the main attraction, are in the six minute range. <br /> <br />This particular version of 'Free Live' comes packaged with a well designed and informative booklet, featuring numerous performance and publicity shots of the band, plenty of details on the individual tracks, and well-composed text detailing the short-lived history of the band.  The recording is as clean and well-defined as any recording I've heard from the era. 'Free' possessed a great deal of heart and attitude, and coupled with Rogers pristine vocals and Kossoff's intense guitar work, this product clamours for a listen even 36 years after the tracks were laid down.  It's not essential, but it is enjoyable.  And of course, turn it up loud for maximum listening pleasure!
B000002IHD|4.0|This is probably Redding's most famous and acclaimed single LP; it's one of only two that Rhino keeps in print domestically at mid-price. (The other is the ubiquitous semi-compilation, DOCK OF THE BAY). Redding's incredible force of personality carries all of his LPs, and they're all quality entertainment, but most of them are erratic. OTIS BLUE is as uneven as any of them but contains a handful of seminal performances. <br /> <br />Side A is much stronger than side B, and contains all of the original material Redding brought to this session. As expected, the three originals are all outstanding. \\"I've Been Loving You Too Long\\" is a justly famous, dynamic torch ballad; \\"Ole Man Trouble\\" (repeated, perhaps to more poignant effect, on DOCK OF THE BAY) receives a cavernous arrangement, anchored to a dissonant Steve Cropper riff, with lyrics of overwhelming despair. And the version here of \\"Respect\\" is sleeker and punchier than Aretha's, although necessarily it lacks much feminist interest. I prefer it anyway. <br /> <br />There are also three Sam Cooke songs, which suggests that Redding might have had a fuller tribute in mind to the then-recently deceased legend. Otis improves on both \\"Shake\\" and \\"A Change is Gonna Come\\" - the latter is skeletal and gut-wrenching, the former gloriously raunchy. (Despite the album's title, Redding's concerns throughout the album are pretty earthy - a lusty blues showcases Cropper on both sides of the LP, although the performances aren't among Redding's most memorable.)  <br /> <br />Side B features a take on \\"Wonderful World\\" that is more radical, but not nearly apt or successful as the late-Cooke pieces on Side A. There's also a perfunctory version of \\"My Girl\\" that, like the two blues, slows the album's momentum and leads me to wonder why this is usually classed as Redding's masterpiece when discs like THE IMMORTAL OTIS REDDING are just sitting there unnoticed. After an odd (but basically reverent) version of \\"Satisfaction\\", complete with fuzz guitar, Redding takes William Bell by the collar and shakes \\"You Don't Miss Your Water\\" free, cutting to the quick just as he did with \\"A Change Is Gonna Come\\". His rendering of the immortal soul ballad is as eccentric and indispensible as The Byrds'. <br /> <br />Either three-and-a-half or four stars. DOCK OF THE BAY, which is just as cheap and is, to a certain extent, cobbled together (side B extracts tunes from three previous Redding LPs and one Stax compilation) is probably a better starter.

The boy shows surprising maturity when he realizes he made a mistake leaving the penguin and then goes back to find him. What a great lesson to learn, that it's OK to make a mistake, acknowledge it, then take action to amend it!<br /><br />This story illustrates that it's the Journey, the trip along the way, not necessarily just the destination that gives life meaning and value. Furthermore, the values of friendship, companionship, and sharing come through strongly in this story.<br /><br />This book also taps into classic, timeless themes of finding one's way back home, almost like a kid's version of The Odyssey.<br /><br />The watercolors of the book are spectacular, deep and rich. B00006IU73|5.0|This was my first exposure to PT.  Ran across several references to them in other reviews of prog music here on Amazon, so I decided to give (album title) a listen and one-clicked a copy to try out.  First thing I have to say I noticed about the disc was the recording quality.  It is PRISTINE and crystal clear.  Not sure what Steve Wilson and/or his recording engineer did while recording this to make it sound so good, but hats off to them for pulling it off.  This is one of the best sounding CDs I've bought in the last decade.  Second thing that struck me was, while I very much enjoyed the music, it didn't necessarily strike me as being obvious prog-rock.  Rock, yes.  Prog, sort of.  I admit my definition of progressive rock is more defined by the 70's prog sound, and PT reminds me more of early 80's Triumph, Rush or Blue Oyster Cult (peppered with a touch of 90's grunge) than 70's Yes, Genesis, or ELP.  The use of heavier electric guitars layered with some feathery strummed acoustic reminded me of Triumph (or the like) quite a bit.  But is it good music?  Oh yeah...the team Steve Wilson put together consists of solid musicians, and they deliver on here, pulling out powerful performances of his material.  Another aspect of PT I really like are the vocals.  I've moaned in several other reviews about the vocalists in a few other prog bands, and I was pleasantly surprised with Wilson's voice.  He tends to sing in a lower register than a lot of Dream Theatre-inspired prog outfits, and it's a nice change.  I think it better relates the more personal-sounding lyrics Wilson tends to write.  Though I'm not a hard rock fanatic, I tend to like the harder rocking tunes on this.  The ethereal-sounding, slower numbers sound great (production wise) but don't really carry the energy the harder numbers do (the slower songs come across a little more emotionally heavy).  And don't expect any massive B3 or moog solos or any other prog rock keyboard staples.  All the keyboard work is very subtle and textural, flavoring the music much more than leading it.  <br /> <br />Though some of the songs are less than 5s (the slower, keyboard driven numbers for me), the disc as a whole is a work of art for production and musicianship. <br /> <br />So, if you like prog-ish rock with good energy and a darker mood, this is definitely one to consider. <br />

B000002ADT|5.0|If you find most jazz to be too busy, too fast, too sonically dense and not melodic enough to suit your taste, I think you'll find this classic a very pleasant surprise. It has space, it has unforgettable melodies- it is quite simply a subtle gem of the jazz genre. Miles Davis assembled a band of jazz gods including John Coltrane, \\"Cannonball\\" Adderley and Bill Evans. Jimmy Cobb, Paul Chambers and Wynton Kelly round out the ensemble. Mr. Davis provided the band with the frameworks in which they could improvise and off they went to create this gorgeous work. I can't stress enough how peaceful and laid back this music sounds. It's a far cry from Miles' later experiments in jazz fusion (see \\"Bitches Brew\\") and indeed most of the subgenres of jazz.<br /><br />If you love this album like I do, you might also enjoy Coltrane's \\"A Love Supreme\\", Dave Brubeck's \\"Time Out\\" and Charles Mingus' \\"Mingus Ah Um\\". You might also want to check out the artists on the ECM label for examples of more contemporary subtle, spacious jazz but \\"Kind of Blue\\" is number one on my list of terrific jazz albums. Dig that mellow vibe!

B000EMGAOY|5.0|The Red Hot Chili Peppers career can be broken down into 3 distinct segments--the original band with John Frusciante, the \\"Our lead guitarist this week is .....\\" phase and the current Frusciante restoration phase.   <br /> <br />The first phase was characterized by powerful music that forced alternative into the mainstream consciousness.  The albums were uneven, with considerable material that can most charitably be characterized as \\"filler\\", but the masterworks were so powerful one had to have them and resign onself to liberal use of the \\"seek' function on ones stero.  The middle phase is best forgotten.  With the restoration of Frusciante to the band, the Peppers were once again a force to be dealt with. <br /> <br />Stadium Arcadium is a bit of a departure.  Californication, the first element of the restoration period was more in line with the 1st phase--powerful music spaced with filler.  With By the Way the Peppers achieved the ultimate--a perfect album, where every single track was worth listening to and the whole was far greater than the sum of its parts. <br /> <br />This effort lies somewhere in between.  The synergy and cohesiveness of By the Way are not as present in this album.  The lushness and resonance of that effort have given way to a more spare, cleaner sound on this album.  This work, encompassing two discs, is more fragmented and less driven than the last effort.  And, this effort is a more rhythm than melody based composition. <br /> <br />It is, however, all those facts notwithstanding, an extraordinary album.  The lyrics are more nuanced and comprehensible here.  The music more controlled and articulated.  The energy level remains the high octane explosion one expects from the Peppers.  If this album is somewhat devoid of the monster Top 20 type hit, it is nevertheless heavily populated by accessible and memorable tracks. <br /> <br />The Peppers history has been one characterized largely by chaos and extremism.  Frusciante's survival of his nearly fatal herion addiction and the sheer inertia of age has combined to soften the sound and lend a more mature, introspective aspect to their music.  In other words, the Peppers are evolving--and, happily, evolving to a much higher level musically, harmonically and intellectually.  We are all better off for the change. <br />

The only thing this film had in it was two little moments of humor when one of the two ugly b*tches from the club gets ran over by the car, and the oriental girl throws herself in front of the train. When I rent a horror movie, I expect more than a couple of laughs. Hell High Tension was better than this, the end was f#cking stupid, but I enjoyed it allot more.<br /><br /> Have people grown so \\"sensitive\\" that they are now horrified by anything. Was Bambi Two straight to video because it was \\"too hot for theaters?\\" I saw more horror in Nightmare on Elm Street, more gore in Day of the Dead. I cry when I watch horror now. It's not that I have an over abundance of compassion for the characters, it's just too painful to watch a genre that I love going straight to hell. For decades, horror movies had balls, and then, to my surprise, one of the grandfathers of modern horror, Wes Craven himself, made Scream, and nothing has ever been the same since.<br /><br /> This movie will chill you if your one of the millions of brain dead zombies that thought the world of Scream,  Saw Two, (or One for that matter), or any of the countless other mindless horror movies made over the last fifteen or so years. For anyone who wants to see real terror, rent I Spit on Your Grave, or Henry Portrait of a Serial Killer, and feel the pain.

B000EMGAOY|4.0|I agree people need to listen to the \\"Mars\\" portion of this album to really appreciate what Red Hot Chili Peppers wrote for this double-disk album.  However, I'm really appreciative of this album for another reason. <br /> <br />RHCP tried to revive an old way of writing an album.  You may notice that the same melodic theme comes up quite a few times along with repeating chord progressions.  This type of album writing can be seen in artists like Pink Floyd, Bob Dylan, King Crimson or even classical era composers like Bach, Mozart, or Handel in his oratorios.  It was used as a way to tell a story using intertwining/reocurring melodies to tell it. <br /> <br />It may seem repetitive but it is a form of art.  Agreed, RHCP could have explored and diversified the songs a tad more because they do sound a bit too much like the one before, but all in all they did a good job reviving an old artform. <br /> <br />I firmly believe this will become one of those albums we will all see on VH1 some day and an album that the next generation of kids will go and buy like Dark Side of the Moon or Highway 61 Revisited (but certainly not to that extent).  It is definitely an album everyone should try listening all the way through to.

B000069AUI|5.0|Coldplay's second album deserved all the commercial and critical success it achieved, it managed to strike the right balance between their stripped down intimate debut album 'Parachutes' and the anthemic melancholy of the follow up album 'X & Y'. 'A Rush Of Blood To The Head' is dominated by piano-based ballad's which the band excel at and is preferable to the layer's of keyboard's and synths that feature heavily on 'X & Y' (a strong album but definitely over-produced!).<br />I've never been particularly impressed by Chris Martin's lyrics but he get's away with it as he sings with a genuine humanity and passion that is gripping and heartwarming and he's on his best form here. Johnny Buckland play's a subtle role on this album, the guitar's are almost non-existent compared to his playing on 'Parachutes' but they are there when the song's demand them and they serve their role well.<br />'Clocks' is one of those rare songs that has been played to death on radio and television but has never grated on me- in fact, I love 'Clocks' just that little bit more everytime I hear it. The piano riff, Will Champion's drums and Guy Berryman's pulsating bassline help to drive along a song which ranks as my absolute favourite Coldplay tune.<br />'Amsterdam' is a very close second to 'Clocks', it's my favourite closing track to any album I've ever heard and I hope Coldplay don't abandon songs like this in future, whatever direction they choose to take because they are master's of the slow-building piano ballad and 'Amsterdam' is their best effort in that style. 'The Scientist' almost matches it.<br />'In My Place' has a gorgeous tune and is one of their best singles, I've always preferred it over 'Yellow'. 'Daylight' and 'A Whisper' are a couple of my other favourite's from this album.<br />A lot of similar band's have since tried to make an album as consistently strong and emotional as 'A Rush Of Blood To The Head' but none have matched it.
068485743X|5.0|Having collected many slush- pile rejections in my time it was interesting for me to read a bit of what was actually going on on the other side. The obvious fact that a sloppily presented manuscript is readily rejected is one I admit I probably never have completely learned. At Cornell the late David Novarr taught us 'Sloppy punctuation makes for sloppy thought' and this seems to be one of Lukeman's fundamental insights.<br /><br />He goes on to give a number of reasons why manuscripts are readily rejected, including excessive use of modifiers, and wooden trite dialogue.<br /><br />He in fact goes through the stages at which a manuscript is conceivably read pointing out grounds for rejection at each stage.<br /><br />At my age I do not know how much of all of this can be of use to me. But my guess is much of it will be of use to fledgling writers.<br /><br />I think his point about writers' need to devote time to researching the appropriate possible agent for their kind of material, makes a lot of sense. Looking at acknowledgments in books of similar subjects is clearly one way. Finding out from people who might be in the know , if one knows anyone in the know is another. Clearly indicating a knowledge of the Agent's previous work is a way of opening the heart, and perhaps the door a bit.<br /><br />This is a good guide which hopefully will be of use to some of its readers.
B000DWMN2S|5.0|(2005) What a pleasant surprise. Elijah Wood's best role since the \\"Lord Of The Rings's\\" Frodo. Wood plays Jonathan Foer, a young Jewish American who wants to discover his past - and say a special thank you to the woman who helped save his grandfather during the Nazi invasion during WWII. And so Jonathan's European road trip begins. Foer is somewhat neurotic - tagging and bagging life's souvenirs to his bedroom wall. Foer departs the train to find his tour guides... an odd pair, a mid 20-something hipster and his grandfather... and the real journey begins. Both guides are extremely funny at times. Unknown actors to me playing the younger tour guide (Eugene Hutz) and the witty grandfather (Boris Leskin)... not to mention the dog - the \\"official seeing eye [...]\\" by the name of Sammy Davis Junior, Junior. The cinemaphotography is beautiful as Foer is taken through the many rolling hills and small quaint towns. The storyline engrossing; the dialogue sharp; the character's creating empathy; the dog acting cute as can be and barking on queue; the ending fulfilling. I did not read the book, but the movie makes me want to now. A great movie with some truly wonderful messages.

The juxtaposition of Capote, the twisted soul writer, and Perry Smith, the twisted soul killer, reveals the thin line between people who follow different paths in life.  Capote is drawn in to the humanity of a rightfully convicted killer and finds himself shattered in the process.  Tortured souls do create good art though.<br /><br />\\"Capote,\\" could have been more.  We could have gotten under the skin of Truman and revealed complexities barely explored, barely scratched.  Don't expect, \\"Capote,\\" to gain lofty heights on your top ten list but do watch it for Hoffman's performance of a complicated man.<br /><br />--MMW
B00002E233|1.0|Caution: This review contains a couple spoilers! <br /> <br />First off, I have to admit that my husband and I ended up seeing this by accident, when flipping through channels. What is not accidental (and is patently inexcusable, in my opinion) is the sheer awfulness of this movie. It was so bad it was funny, and for that reason alone we watched it for the (surely unintended) comedy.   <br /> <br />The movie is rife with stock and unoriginal characters: whiny useless blonde woman, who can only stand there and scream at critical junctures (almost as vexing as those young women in horror flicks who are running for their lives but always trip and/or fall down), sexy young doctor/bimbo character (I guess she finished that pesky PhD while still in high school), buff blonde himbo (no, that's not a typo, he's just the male surfer version of the bimbo), and a couple of token minorities, one of whom gives preachy pep talks (we actually cheered when in the midst of Jackson's character's \\"we must pull together as a team to survive\\" rah-rah speech, a shark surfaced and gulped him down raw). Yummy. Mr. Shark doesn't fancy that sanctimonious claptrap anymore than we did. <br /> <br />Most amusing scene: bimbo scientist feels it necessary to strip off her wetsuit before she kills a shark, and after all the drama and suspense of the impromptu strip-tease we see she's wearing sensible white undies rather than Victoria's Secret. Aww, what a disappointment. But I guess good girls don't go to heaven if they wear naughty underwear.  <br /> <br />More things we picked up on: whenever a character cusses, drinks, smokes, or looks at porn, something terrible happens. Evil shark suddenly appears and punishes said sinner. Hardly subtle. (For example, one guy lights up a cigarette and seconds later loses a hand - hubby said this was the best anti-smoking campaign ad ever!) There are probably more than a dozen references to God throughout this film, which in itself is not objectionable, but becomes obvious and annoying after more than a couple times. There's even a \\"group hug\\" scene where all the characters join hands in a circle and pray. What is this, the 700 Club? Not to mention a shark gets stabbed with a crucifix in the end. Spare us the lofty moral overtones and get on with the story already. Oh wait, that would require a plot, wouldn't it?   <br /> <br />A lot of people have been comparing this movie to \\"Jaws.\\" I'm not sure what they've been smoking (careful there, might lose a hand!;), but the only thing this joke of a film has in common with \\"Jaws\\" is the CGI effects might as well date from the 70s. There's no excuse for a 1999 film to have CGI so terribly bad that it's just plain embarrassing after awhile. Cast should have done shadow-puppets on a wall instead - I think it would have been scarier. More entertaining, too. <br /> <br />This movie is so predictable, so corny, and so appallingly bad that I wonder if the actors even dare list it on their resumes.

1580084621|5.0|I have been cooking Thai food on a semi-profesional level for more than 15 years. Teaching Thai cooking, running a Thai chef service and cooking for family and friends. I have taken private cooking lessons with chefs in Thailand and I am addicted to both the culture and food of this beautiful country.     When I got David Thomson's book for my birthday, I was both very happy and very sad. Happy, because I had finally found the ultimate Thai cookbook. A book that reads like a blend between a dictionary, history book and fantastic cook book. Sad, because at the moment I opened the first page I knew that my dream of writing a Thai cookbook had come to an end. There is nothing more to be said or written. David Thomson has done it. I recommend this book to all people serious about Thai cooking.
