067182449X|4.0|Anne Frank- The Diary of a Young Girl is an inspiring and uplifting story during which not only readers learn about the circumstances and events of the time of World War II, but gain insights into the true meaning of life from a teenage girl opening up her heart to her diary. She changes the meaning of life and happiness while hiding in a warehous for more than two years. She dramatically changes from a girl to a young woman who falls in love, is extremely independent, and finds happiness in the darkest of situations. Although the middle of the diary is a little dry, her story is still amazing and keeps readers' attention, especially as her deepest thoughts, feelings, hopes, and dreams are poured out. Particularly when she says that she wants to remain alive even after she's dead, readers know that this girl is special. Finally, her diary ends, as she is finally found and set to a concentration camp; yet her dream came true because she is still alive in all of us deep down today.
1400079179|3.0|This is the type of novel that is best read before the hype, considering once you read it after the hype, it becomes entirely an act of sorting through other people's thoughts and arguments about what it becomes in the end and \\"choosing a side, so to speak.\\"  So when approaching this novel so controversial in quality, I speak only of my responses to others' arguments, ones obtained without even searching or asking for them.<br /><br />So I will begin with the now pop-lore level overview of the book: a \\"symbologist\\" named Robert Langdon is called to investigate a murder at the Louvre, and he doesn't know why.  Half-an-hour, a new female friend (to quote Monty python: \\"Hint hint nudge nudge wink wink say no more, say no more), and a bunch of enemies later, Langdon is in a race to uncover a multigenerational, internation conspiracy involving a lot of Da Vinci, a lot of Christian analysis, and quite a lot of allusions to the idea that maybe the Catholic church ain't so benevolent an institution.<br /><br />In general it's a pretty engaging thriller, interesting and keeps up a fast, fun pace.  If it wasn't nearly as famous, I'd go as far as to say it'd be pretty much liked by everyone who found it.  If it less-than-popular, it would be a cult classic that was \\"underminded by the status quo\\" and kept out of the limelight because of the controversial ideas it presents.<br /><br />Instead, it's rather famous, with all of the angry fundamentalist Christians saying it shouldn't exist out there necessary to code it deep within our souls that this novel MIGHT BE SAYIN' SOMETHIN'!  Goodness knows it isn't an important work if it doesn't anger da Krishtens.<br /><br />Which is funny, because once again, if they had actually read the entire thing, they might have realized that it's ultimate view of Christianity is not as demeaning.  Funny how often that happens.<br /><br />But of course, I can understand them their not wanting to read further, as the book pretty much presents a plethora of fast-paced ideas without really working on some of the more, shall we say, \\"literate\\"? aspects of the novel.  When people say that this was written to be a movie, they are not lying.  I could see the shots all planned out, but none of the character development we expect from the ability to crawl into these characters' consciencenesses.  \\"He got shot, and felt pain.\\"  That's basically as far as it goes with character development.<br /><br />Indeed, the whole power of the book rests on two things: interesting ideas, and thrills.  The interesting ideas are about as controversial as the book itself: are they real, fabricated, or just misrepresented?  The answer to that pretty much depends on how interested you are in the subject matter and what you know.  Let me put it this way: if you don't know anything about art history and want an entertaining fiction, it's a great novel.  If you're some crazy intelligent person who actually knows about all the information on the book, you'll be too busy nitpicking to enjoy it's, let's call it FICTIONAL, elements.  Because despite the little thing in the front that claims truth, this is a fiction, buddy, and should be taken as such.<br /><br />No, where I actually pull my problems with the novel comes from the things people call it's greatest strength: it's suspense.  Sure, it moves at a breakneck speed, but it moves at a breakneck speed so willing to give denouement to each chapter that you can leave the car at any moment relatively unharmed.  The puzzles, riddles, and such run the gamut between ingenious and obvious (sometimes I was all like \\"Dude, this CAN'T mean anything... oh...\\" and sometimes I was like, \\"Why is it taking half a second for them to figure this one out?\\"), but all of them are given their solution within fifteen pages.  Gripping suspense that is not.  Anyone can rest easy knowing the next big moment of the book is just another five minute's read away, usually with enough expository dialog, (\\"I'm glad you asked, now let me tell you!\\") to know when it's okay to take a break.  The in-book timeline may be short (over the course of less than 24 hours), by the book's thickness is not created by a full twenty four hours of direct action.<br /><br />I think the book could have used some minor dieting.  Lose a couple unnecessary characters, not be so repetitive with the flashbacks (or here's a thought, take them out completely...), do a bit o' the ol' \\"Show, don't tell...\\"  In fact, it went through such lengths to tie up every loose thread that basically nothing was left to the imagination.  That's disappointing, as the book itself is a great medium from which to express these ideas to do something called \\"making people think.\\"  Instead it just kind of finishes everything and then even goes as far as to take the time to explain that it is, in itself, metaphorical and symbolic as well!  Good job there, Mr. Brown.<br /><br />At this point, it's pretty much up to you how much you enjoy it.  What you're expecting is exactly what you'll get out of it.  If you've seen the movie, the book is unnecessary, because you've seen everything and it was written to be a movie.  If you've read the book, the movie is unnecessary, because you've basically read everything and even have the implied shot list.<br /><br />In the end it's basically just another decent pulp novel.<br /><br />--PolarisDiBlog, (\\"I'm glad you asked, now let me tell you!\\") to know when it's okay to take a break.  The in-book timeline may be short (over the course of less than 24 hours), by the book's thickness is not created by a full twenty four hours of direct action.   <br /> <br />I think the book could have used some minor dieting.  Lose a couple unnecessary characters, not be so repetitive with the flashbacks (or here's a thought, take them out completely...), do a bit o' the ol' \\"Show, don't tell...\\"  In fact, it went through such lengths to tie up every loose thread that basically nothing was left to the imagination.  That's disappointing, as the book itself is a great medium from which to express these ideas to do something called \\"making people think.\\"  Instead it just kind of finishes everything and then even goes as far as to take the time to explain that it is, in itself, metaphorical and symbolic as well!  Good job there, Mr. Brown.   <br /> <br />At this point, it's pretty much up to you how much you enjoy it.  What you're expecting is exactly what you'll get out of it.  If you've seen the movie, the book is unnecessary, because you've seen everything and it was written to be a movie.  If you've read the book, the movie is unnecessary, because you've basically read everything and even have the implied shot list.   <br /> <br />In the end it's basically just another decent pulp novel. <br /> <br />--PolarisDiB
B000EBEHR2|5.0|Wow. This really took me by surprise. After hearing it was supposedly much more \\"stripped down\\" compared to Sleeping With Ghosts, I feared the worst. I expected Meds to be much more organic and grungy, without the beautiful electronic textures that made Sleeping With Ghosts so warm and interesting. I was completely misled! Meds is far and away the best Placebo yet. There are still plenty of electronic touches and smooth, catchy melodies. And at the same time, it manages to rock your socks off. <br /> <br />The one thing I don't understand is their decision to make \\"Because I Want You\\" a single. It is by far the worst song on the album, and one of only two that I don't love (the other being the Michael Stipe duet, \\"Broken Promise\\"). <br /> <br />There are so many other good tracks, though, it's unbelievable. My absolute favorites are the menacing \\"Infra-Red,\\" the semi-experimental \\"Space Monkey,\\" and the gorgeous ballad \\"Pierrot The Clown.\\" Not far behind are \\"Drag,\\" \\"Post Blue,\\" and \\"Song To Say Goodbye.\\" <br /> <br />I can't believe how many people think Meds and Sleeping With Ghosts are Placebo's worst. I couldn't disagree more with these people! Brian Molko and the boys have created a masterpiece. I typically listen to bands that lean slightly more toward the electro-pop or new wave end of the pop spectrum, and some of my favorite bands have released brilliant new albums this year... which is why I'm so shocked to find that I keep returning to Meds. Somehow it's managed to push its way to #1 on my list of 2006 releases. I love it.

From the early White Stripes albums to \\"Candy Cane Children\\" to Loretta Lynn's \\"Van Lear Rose\\" to the music from COLD MOUNTAIN to \\"Get Behind Me Satan\\" to The Raconteurs, you just never know what he's going to do next. You can count on two things though: it will not be a copy of what he's done before and it will be quality music.  <br />I believe he's the best composer and best musician in rock music today (and will be tomorrow).  <br />The Raconteurs debut album is 10 infectious tracks that have a timeless quality. Instead of fronting the band, Jack's style is incorporated into a group of incredibly talented performers. 0440236304|5.0|A narrative of suspense, action, and horror set inside the mind of Donald Burgett as he struggled to become one of the members of the elite 101st Airborne Division and ultimately survive through World War II. Currahee is written such that one feels as if he is following the main character, Burgett, step by bloody step. This first person narration by the hardened war veteran, Burgett, adds a suspense and gritty realization to the horrors of war. Every chapter focuses around Burgett's adventures and deadly battles he encountered regularly. He describes in detail every action he took, and every shot he fired so that the reader can never miss a beat. He explains his training and how damn near impossible it was to become a paratrooper. The joke going around during his first day of boot camp in 1942 went, \\"If two doctors were on each side of you lookin' in your ears and could see each other, you were a new member of the 101st Airborne!\\" At only 18 years old, Burgett had the heart and mind of sure will and determination. He did whatever he had to do in order to pass the required training and receive his jump wings, qualifying him as one of the best in the army. I am convinced that Burgett and his entire generation who were tough enough to make it into the 101st became the most admirable \\"bunch of guys\\" this nation has ever had for now and generations to come. We, the people, of the United States of America owe them our solemn gratitude and utmost respect that they laid down their lives so that your children, and my children, might be able to live in freedom for years to come. <br /> <br />I would not recommend this book to anyone under the age of 15. Not only can the language be foul, but the amount of detail in the actual WWII fighting can become too much to endure for young teenagers. The amount of agony, blood, and gore described even left me sick to my stomach and filled with sadness over the amount of death of those brave American soldiers. These citizen soldiers werejust like you and I, working part time at the grocery store and helping their parents clean the table after supper. But when the time came, they all went out to defend their country without hesitation, without remorse for the enemy. That is the beautiful part of this book, that men such as Burgett would answer the call and damn well know that they were risking their lives for the sake of their mothers, fathers, and all of people who lived in this country. That is why every time I read this book I cannot put it down because I know that Burgett was MY AGE when he was in the fields of Normandy risking his life to preserve the sacred word, freedom. With such eminent detail, I often find myself ducking my head thinking that those bullets are going to strike me. I often wondered, \\"He was killing Germans while I am still learning Math, how weak and insignificant I must be compared to him.\\" When I read the first page, I could not stop until I reached page one hundred and fifty. So please, pick up a copy of Currahee and become engulfed with a true story about how self-sacrifice and military excellence ultimately won World War II and preserved freedom to this day.  <br />

1400079276|4.0|This is my first Murakami book. Prior to reading Kafka on the Shore, i was told that he has written better books. Obviously, I have nothing to measure it against but I must say that if this is not his best book, I'm definitely in for a treat when I read his earlier ones.  <br /> <br />Parallels between the two journeys or stories of Kafka Tamura and Mr. Nakata are underscored on several occasions. Actions in one story always affect the other and such a plot structure invariably compels the reader to draw intersections of the two stories on his or oher own. This, i would say, accounts greatly for the intrigue or addictiveness of the novel as it engages us and forces us to accept such dreamlike-ness as perfectly plausible. Given the title, I guess one can say anything less than such bizarreness would be a great disappointment.  <br /> <br />The fact that many parts are left unexplained towards the end also compound the bizarreness. Either Murakami has ran out of steam here or simply refuses to tie the plot neatly together. Personally, i'm inclined towards the former cos I think a much better crafted plot (even when that stresses on uncertainty) would at least leave one with some suggestions to ponder over.  <br /> <br />Overall though, the book is compelling and entertaining. Characterization, for one, is intriguing, especially because of the hermaphrodite, Oshima. In him/her, i think the novel seeks to epitomize the essence of its plot--the overwhelming uncertainties, and blurring and impossibility of distinctions or dichotomies in the current world; life is but a dream. Also, I wonder if the constant references to past, memories and war are a nod to the impact of Japan's militaristic past. In any case, this is a book i would recommend to friends. Definitely an interesting read.

I always found it hard to believe that any large group of humans could ever reach the level of peace & harmony that would be required for anything like the Federation of Planets to exist.  I loved the stories, but found it was simply a fairy tale.  Now this is something totally different.  Scalzi's universe is the one that needs a cult following. Free from the constraints of religious based fear of scientific advancement, how long do you think it would take them to leave us technologically in the dust?  They'd be so far ahead of us in 1 generation's time we would never recover.  They'd be free of all diseases & working towards colonizing new planets, while we would still be here trying to figure out athlete's foot.  That's the Colonial Union.  Scalzi has given us an image of the future that could very well BE our future. The story is quick-paced, but not scattered.  It moves along well, but still allows for enough character development so you care about John Perry & his group of \\"Old Farts\\"!  The idea of getting to be 75 & then given a chance to become young again doesnt hurt either! LOL!  This is a must read for anyone who loves the science-fiction genre!

0684824906|2.0|The book suffers from two flaws that in my opinion are ultimately fatal.<br /><br />1.) The writing suffers from the over-use of indefinite pronouns. Before the end of the second chapter, you will be annoyed by the number of sentences which are impenetrable because there are three or four actors ... all of whom are referred to in the sentence as \\"he\\".  Which he did what is left as an exercise to the reader.<br /><br />2.) Equally unfortunately, some of the most important developments in Lincoln's thinking are presented as fact but inadequately defended or not defended at all.  It becomes unclear whether Lincoln's ultimate motivation was, for instance, to free slaves or to create a place for himself in history.<br /><br />The first failure is merely annoying; the second effort dooms the book.  By the end of the book, I was convinced that the only difference between Lincoln and Bush II was that Lincoln had picked a cause that he could actually win.<br /><br />This book was for me ultimately depressing, and more so because I had to work so hard to understand it.  Here's an easy example I picked simply by opening the book and reading until I found one.  I opened to late on page 567, and in the first full paragraph of page 568, the last two sentences are as follows (actors in the first part of the paragraph are Bates, Gamble, and Chase.)<br /><br />\\"Gamble replied that Bates should hardly be shocked by Chase's willingness to entertain \\"these persons,\\" for \\"Mr. Chase is the author of our troubles here.\\"  His \\"criminal ambition\\" for the presidency had led him to incite the struggle, and he would undoubtedly have the support of every radical paper in the state if he were to decide to run against Lincoln\\"<br /><br />To understand the book you have to determine who the \\"he\\" is here (if, as appears to be the case in this instance, \\"he\\" only refers to one person, which is rarely the case in the book) and whether or not the statement \\"undoubtedly have the support of every radical paper in the state\\" is:<br /><br />1.) the opinion of Gamble<br />2.) supported by other facts<br />3.) referring to a specific state, and if so what state<br /><br />The author wasn't quoting Gamble, so why not just insert the name of the state?  Gah!  And this was an easy example.<br /><br />Perhaps I am overburdening the author with a need to write clearly.  But unclear writing often follows from unclear thinking.  Therefore the writing undermines the credibility of the book ... especially since the writing is supposed to be showing the state of Lincoln's mind, and Lincoln had an unusual ability to show his thinking in clear, concise speeches.f Gamble  2.) supported by other facts   3.) referring to a specific state, and if so what state    The author wasn't quoting Gamble, so why not just insert the name of the state?  Gah!  And this was an easy example.     Perhaps I am overburdening the author with a need to write clearly.  But unclear writing often follows from unclear thinking.  Therefore the writing undermines the credibility of the book ... especially since the writing is supposed to be showing the state of Lincoln's mind, and Lincoln had an unusual ability to show his thinking in clear, concise speeches.
B000E1ZBGS|5.0|From the breathtaking English countryside to the finely-honed performances, this movie is a real delight.  All of Jane Austen's characters are there:  the long-suffering Mr. Bennett, the manic, matchmaking Mrs. Bennett, the lovely Jane, the feisty Elizabeth, the dour Mr. Darcy, the affable Mr. Bingley, and the imperious Lady Catherine.  Many of the lines are taken directly from the book, and the important plots and subplots are all there.  The sharp divisions between social classes are evident, as is the scheming behind who is to marry which man and receive which yearly income.  The casting is superb, from Donald Sutherland as the befuddled and very much outnumbered male in the Bennett household to Judi Dench, in the small but pivotal role of Lady Catherine.  \\"Pride and Prejudice\\" is one of my favorite books and this movie truly does it justice.
0316172324|3.0|There are a few good ideas in here, which attracted me (as well as millions of others) to pick up this book.  I am impressed at the sheer number of people he's convinced to buy his book at first blink.  However, Mr Gladwell ultimately falls victim to his own preachings as he seems to shun the alternative logical, methodical way of doing things, resulting in a work with a few interesting but embryonic ideas and no clear flow of themes. <br /> <br />What really rankled with me was the writing.  It's appalling.  From Chapter One: \\"He's gotten so good at thin-slicing marriages that he says he can be in a restaurant and eavesdrop on the couple one table over and get a pretty good sense of whether they need to start thinking about hiring lawyers and dividing up custody of the children.\\"  This is undoubtedly the most tortuous sentence I've read in print.  Come on Mr Gladwell, haven't you heard that \\"it don't mean a thing if it ain't got that swing\\"? <br /> <br />Perhaps he should have taken a cue from \\"Freakonomics\\" author Steven Levitt and gotten a journalist to do the writing for him.  In addition, the editing is just sloppy.  The frequent typos quite spoiled for me this otherwise fairly entertaining light read.  It's an informal collation of behavioural experiments and amusing incidents illustrating triumphs of instinct, but don't expect to walk away with a clearer understanding of how and when to use this intuition any better.  I'm just glad I borrowed it because I wouldn't have paid to read this.

B000F1IQMS|5.0|Steven Spielburgh's \\"Munich\\" is a fearless classic.  He takes the 1972 Olympic slayings of innocent Israeli athletes and recreates the ordeal in all its horrifying detail.  We get some of the footage from ABC's \\"Wide World of Sports\\" to create authenticity, but the reinactment has all the immediacy and horror of \\"Schindler's List\\" and more.  After the outrage, one of Golda Meier's trusted bodyguards (Eric Bana) is summoned to join a team of assassins meant to seek vengeance on the perpetrators.  The vast majority of the movie focuses on the complexity, the obsession, and the miscalculations that come from this type of counter-terrorism.  The missteps are harrowing.  The most touching scene is when they are set to bomb an assassin at his residence, but they immediately need to stop it when his adorable little daughter unexpectedly reappears.      There has been much commentary made about the agenda of this movie.  Despite any stance, Spielburgh has made a relevant movie, a true movie, at a crucial time.  The movie questions the premise of festering violence and its consequences.  It does so through the dialogue without preaching, but mainly through the action which is often horrifying and brimming with suspense.  There are two matching scenes, one at the beginning and one at the end, where the maverick protagonist has an intimate scene with his wife.  It doesn't really give away too much of the movie, but it frames the theme of the film.  He has become a hero to his people for requiting the crimes of the extremists, but it illustrates that he has done so at a high personal price.

0553582461|5.0|I read Assassin's Apprentice almost 2 years ago.  I liked Hobb's writing but the story really didn't captivate me at all.  The pacing was very slow and the plot never seemed to go anywhere until the very end.  The next 2 in the trilogy sat on my shelf for a long while, and finally, some months back, I decided I would give her series another try and I picked up Royal Assassin.  This time, I was hooked right away.  The characters enthralled me, and her unpredictable plot and story twists kept me on the edge of my seat.  I didn't hesitate to pick up the Liveship series and finished those wonderful books very quickly, and then went right into the Tawny Man.  Her trilogies just keep getting better and better. <br />Fool's Fate stars a little slow, but once Fitz and many of the other characters depart and the story gets going, it doesn't stop.  Hobb has a way of keeping you excited and enthralled without having to use a lot of action, and rewards the reader when the action sequences do come about, though there's so much emotional attachment to the characters, her action sequences are almost difficult to read for not knowing the outcome.   <br />One of Hobb's greatest strenghts is writing the relationships between her characters, especially between Fitz and everyone else.  Her books seem to be a character drama that happens to have a fantasy backdrop.  Normally this would not appeal to me, but she does it so darn well.  I find myself anticipating charcter relations and reunions more than I anticipate plot developments. <br />Eventually all good things come to an end, even this book at a hefty 900+ pages.  I won't reveal much for those who haven't read it, but I have to say that I was scared at how Hobb might end the series.  As long time fans will surely know, Fitz hasn't always gotten the long end of the stick.  But the ending was great, it was a perfect balance of bitter and sweet and I don't know of a better way that it could have ended.  I even cried... that's right, Icried at the end.  I didn't realize until it was over how attached I was to these characters and was very sad to see them go.   <br />For me, Hobb has moved herself into the Fantasy Hall of Fame with George R.R. Martin and Guy Gavriel Kay.  I will keep her books on my shelves always and look forward to reading them all again in the future.   <br />Long live Fitz and the Fool as legends of our time...

0764113496|2.0|These kinds of books are a joke in my opinion. I suppose that some incredibly lazy Russian language student could find the answer to some obvious question that they should be figuring out on their own. Anyone that is lazy and is learning Russian is learning the wrong language; better stick with pig latin.    Russian verbs is a very complex subject and you can buy many books in Russia that are just devoted to verbs or motion or perfective/imperfective and they are all clear as mud usually.    There are good spelling dictionaries you can buy from Russia that have every verb know there in case there are some participles or gerunds that you are unsure of but the rest you can find out in a regular dictionary and derive using rules you learn in the first few weeks of studying Russian.    My general advice is that unless you are very sure what you are buying, DO NOT buy any books on Russian written by non native speakers. In general non native speakers can't hit the broad side of barn with their understanding of Russian.    Get \\"5000 Russian Words With All Their Inflected Forms: A Russian-English Dictionary by Richard L. Leed and Slava Paperno  \\". This is an infinitely better book. There is really no comparison.    I bought the 501 Russian verbs book and I never use it.     Whereas the one I mentioned is very useful and well organized.    In general, I would not buy any books on Russian that are by non native speakers. There are a very few exceptions but this is not one of them.    I actually question the usefullness of this whole series of books. You need to learn verbs in context of actual Russian movies or books or real speech you hear. If you try and use them by learning them in a dictionary, the result will be laughable.    For example, when you hear an imperative a lot or see it a lot, you will learn it and then know it and how and when it is used. Do you really expect to look up an imperative in a dictionary and use it correctly? That is such a laughable notion. Especially in Russian!

B000C65Z1G|3.0|The problem with this movie is that at its core it is a standard plot cliche.  There's little more here than the old Hollywood standby \\"evil profit mongering corporation driven by a corrupt CEO and/or politician\\".  Typically, this leaves only the context and the characters involved in the struggle as the fresh and interesting aspects of the movie.   <br /> <br />The context and setting works well enough...the cinematography was attractive and much time is devoted to depicting the plight of poverty and the struggle to live amidst rampant disease and lawlessness in remote Africa.  You also get a good sense of what aid workers (or anyone else helping in those regions) are up against...the numbers are so overwhelming that you know you can't help them all, but what if you can help this one right here, right now?  How do you choose which ones to help and when?  When do you bend the rules, and what are the consequences?  Thought provoking notions in refreshingly compact dialog that doesn't get too preachy. <br /> <br />Ultimately, the characters involved fail to drive the movie, and that's a problem since there's not a lot of fast-paced action happening as the coverup is unravelled (as you get in something like \\"The Bourne Identity\\"), so the characters are all you really have.  The most notable flaw is the fact that the timeline jumps around on the main characters too much for you to build an adequate sense of what they're about or to care what happens to them.  Tessa's anti-Iraq rantings felt a little too much like a trendy Hollywood copout instead of a solid backdrop for her political motivations.  Is she more interested in helping and protecting the disadvantaged?  Or simply sticking it to the establishment?  Sure, the two intersect frequently...but you never get a true sense of what is truly driving her.  Justin works a little better as the \\"Constant Gardener\\", just oblivious to everything going on under his nose until he quite passively uncovers Tessa's involvment inthe drug testing coverup and decides to finish what she started to honor her memory. 038572179X|3.0|Atonement is bestselling author Ian McEwan's latest novel. Atonement tells the story of 13 year old Briony Tallis. The book opens with Briony attempting to produce her childhood drama The Trials of Arabella with her cousins. Briony, is the youngest of three children and the daughter of ever absent parents Jack and Emily Tallis. Jack is a minister who works in the Home Office, and Emily tries to be there constantly for Briony but is under constant fear of severe migraines. Briony has two older siblings; Cecilia who is ten years older, and Leon who is almost twenty two years older than Briony. <br /> At the beginning of the story, Briony Tallis lives outside of London with her parents, sister and her cousins. The cousins moved in with her while their parents are going through a nasty divorce during the summer of 1935. Briony attempts to produce her play with her cousins to no avail. During these rehearsals Briony witnesses the sexual interaction between her 23 year old sister Cecilia and the gardener, Robbie Turner. Cecilia and Robbie see there relationship as normal while Briony sees it as assaulting. This leads Briony to accuse Robbie of raping her 15 year old cousin, Lola after she witnessing the raping one dark evening during the summer. Since Briony is the only witness she is vital in sending Robbie to jail. He is later allowed to join the British Expeditionary Force in France as conditions of parole. While Robbie is in jail and the army, Cecilia continues to stay in touch with him and not let there love die, but she does disconnect herself from her family. <br /> Briony continues to succeed in life and becomes a nurse, like her older sister. Briony later learns that Lola was raped by Paul Marshall, Leon Tallis's friend. After learning that she had falsely accused Robbie of the rape which Paul had in fact committed and a confrontation with her sister, Briony realizes that she must atone for her wrong doings and reveal her story to the whole world. This takes Briony nearly six decades but when she finally finishes her story she learns that she is being faced with a terminal illness and that her book will be published posthumously. In doing so, she changes the ending of the story to a happy one instead for the reality of Robbie and Cecilia both dying.  <br /> Atonement is divided up into four sections which allow the plot to develop uniquely. Part 1 focuses on the background of the story and leads up to the arrest of Robbie Turner for raping Lola Quincey. Part 2 follows Robbie while he is on parole and required to join the British Expeditionary Force in France. Part 2 allows the reader to know that Robbie is in constant contact with his true love, Cecilia Tallis, who at that point is estranged from Briony. Part 3 focuses on Briony's nurse's training in London during the war. Part 3 deals with the bombing of Dunkirk, the marriage between Lola and Paul Marshall, and Briony's confrontation with her sister about what really happened on the matter of the rape. Part 4 or \\"London 1999\\" occurs on Briony's 77th birthday. At this point the reader learns that the previous three parts are Briony's writing to try to atone for her 1935 wrong doing, told in a fictional way. <br />Atonement was written well, but it did not capture my attention one hundred percent. There were times when I couldn't put the book the down but they were outnumbered by the times that I just couldn't get into the story. However, I did enjoy the way that the story was divided and the fictional/factional aspects that were told. <br />
0679422714|1.0|I teach Chinese politics at the college level.  I assign Jung Chang's excellent autobiography, Wild Swans, to my class.  My students love it, and with good reason.  It captures the ever-changing complexities of China in the 20th century as few books can.  Therefore, I was eagerly anticipating the publication of Mao: The Untold Story.  However, not only have I been disappointed, I am appalled!  Books like this serve to dumb down the next generation of people with a casual interest in China and Mao.<br /><br />First, the book is written in a style that approximates a book-length version of a Red Guard poster.  Every sentence is a polemic.  Each paragraph is sure to remind the reader (in case he or she forgot what was written in the previous paragraph) of just how evil and horrible Mao was.  Indeed, the thesis of the books is that Mao was so horrible, that he had absolutely no redeeming qualities.  Now, no serious China scholar would disagree with the statement that Mao was an unlovable person and an increasingly poor ruler after 1958.  In this, the book does not tell us much new (and as the book gets closer to the last decade of Mao's life it becomes somewhat less egregiously inaccurate).  But denying Mao his place in history by arguing that he was simply a scheming manipulator whose monstrousness was matched only by his incompetence makes no sense.  The Chinese had many potential leaders to choose from after May 4th 1919, and the history of the CCP is full of intrigue.  Anybody who rose to the top must have been ruthless and manipulative.  But they must also have been extraordinarily competent, if only to survive.  If Mao was the imbecile that Chang and Halliday make him out to be, this could simply not have occurred.<br /><br />In addition, the book boasts a list of interviews and interviewees that is quite stunning in its scope and in terms of the incredible access obtained by the authors.  Alas, the result is an almost criminal exercise in missed opportunities.  Apart from citing Michael Caine (whom I love as an actor) as an expert on the Korean War, and the now-famous 90+ year-old woman in Luding who denied the entire Luding Bridge episode during the Long March, the authors interviewed a number of my senior colleagues in the China field.  Instead of listening to the more nuanced accounts that these scholars were attempting to provide, Chang and Halliday (according to several of these China scholars), but especially Chang, simply did not want to hear any information that contradicted her central thesis that Mao was evil and incompetent.  As a result, although these China experts are cited in the interviewee list at the back of the book, the data that they were uniquely qualified to provide did not appear in the book itself.  I will assign the book in my social science research courses as an example of how NOT to interview experts in the field.  One is reminded of the brilliant Monty Python sketch in which there is a TV show featuring as guests Karl Marx, Lenin, Che Guevara, and Mao Zedong and instead of actually holding a substantive discussion, the guests are asked to guess the winner of the Eurovision Song Contest and the nicknames of British soccer teams.  [..]<br /><br />Another serious problem in the book is that the authors reinterpret largely settled issues in 20th century China.  There is nothing wrong with revisionism per se if it provides new light on a previously misunderstood event.  Usually, however, such Perry Mason-like moments in scholarship are few and far between.  If a scholar is lucky, he or she can publish one or two books that refute the existing paradigm on a major substantive subject.  But in this book, there are dozens of such refutations.  This means that either the scholarly community got it wrong and Chang and Halliday somehow got it all right, or that Chang and Halliday played fast and loose with facts and interpretations.  Now, I am no believer of maintaining sacred cows in academia, but one cannot but be suspicious of Chang and Halliday's Oliver Stone-like approach to China scholarship, especially given what we can infer from their less-than-disinterested approach to interviewing the participants.  This book is the JFK of China studies.<br /><br />The reason why it is important to lay out the problems with this book is because Chang and Halliday have the type of access to the general reading public that most scholars can only dream of, given the success of Wild Swans and the advertising campaign that surrounded Mao: The Untold Story.  I would urge people to read The Politics of China edited by Roderick MacFarquhar or Governing China by Ken Lieberthal.  If these are too \\"dry\\" for the average reader, they should read Philip Short's Mao: A Life or Li Zhisui's The Secret Life of Chairman Mao.  [...]

B000002542|5.0|Do not buy this album if you want to hear preppy pop hits.  This album is pure rock and roll.   <br />Journey started when Santana lead vocalist and keyboardist Gregg Rollie and Santana guitarist Neal Schon left Santana after the Caravanserai album.  Carlos and Santana drummer Michael Shrieve wanted to play more jazz influenced music, while Gregg and Neal wanted to play more of the music that made the band famous, rock and roll with afro-latin rhythms.  Consequently, Gregg and Neal split and formed their own group.  In December 31, 1973, Journey played their first gig at the Winterland in San Francisco, opening up for \\"The New Santana Band.\\"  Eventually, Journey released their self-titled debut.  You can still hear the Santana influence in this album, except without all the percussion.  This album rocks hard all the way.  Since it's mostly instrumental, you can really see the musical talent that the bandmembers have, especially Neal Schon and Gregg Rollie.  After Steve Perry came in, the music became much more lyrical, and Neal Schon's breathtaking guitar was mostly heard as backup, and keyboards were used only for emotional effects, as opposed to being a driving force of the music, as heard in this album. <br />If you want to hear great classic rock with plenty of guitar and Hammond Organ flourishes, buy this album.  It's an excellent album, and the great price makes it an offer not to be passed up.

The characters are aging people from earth who are transformed into hyper-soldiers to fight aliens. The science (I'm a hard core devote) is absent or implausible, and the action is a series of chiches. For example, at boot camp the sargent delivers a brutal speech about the horrors of war, ho-hum.
B000F48CD8|4.0|As a huge White Stripes fan, when I heard that Jack White was joining up with Brendan Benson, \\"Little Jack\\" Lawrence, and Patrick Keeler, I thought, \\"Hey, he can do what he wants. Nothing wrong with a side project.\\" So when Steady, As She Goes and Store Bought Bones became available for download, I listened and came to the conclusion that they were good and this album would probably be good enough to hold me over until The White Stripes came back from their temporary hiatus. <br /> <br />But the more I listened to them, the more I liked them, especially Store Bought Bones. I started to look more into them and became more interested. I got a few bootlegs, most notably their 3rd-ever concert from Newcastle on 3/22/06, and I started to really anticipate this album. <br /> <br />The clips and bootlegs I heard were really starting to sound awesome, and soon I was almost creaming myself in anticipation. I finally got the album the other day, and I am left speechless. <br /> <br />Not really. If I was left speechless, I wouldn't be typing this. But I was amazed. I could no longer think of this has \\"Jack's little side project.\\" The energy and time put into these songs are amazing, and every single song delivered. When I listened to the album the whole way through the first time, I had to listen to it again! <br /> <br />1. Steady, As She Goes - The first single from this album has amazing staying power. It doesn't get old, at least not in my mind. Every time I hear it is like hearing it for the first time. The only difference is that I like it a lot more now! Great vocal deliveries and a catchy bass line. <br /> <br />2. Hands - This was one of my favorite songs from the bootlegs, especially the live video version that's available here on Amazon. I like this album version a LOT too, although it's a tiny bit slower. But that doesn't detract from it. The harmonies are awesome, and it gets stuck in my head frequently. <br /> <br />3. Broken Boy Soldier - The title track is oneof, if not my single favorite song on the album. You could close your eyes and swear this is a long-lost Zeppelin song. From the funky acoustic guitars to Jack's searing vocal delivery, it screams Zeppelin. Everything about this song is perfect! <br /> <br />4. Intimate Secretary - Another one of my favorite songs on the album. Playful lyrics and playful vocal delivery. The harmonies between Brendan and Little Jack in the verses sound friggin awesome, and Jack sounds great in the chorus. This song is really a group effort, and you can't help but sing along with the childish lyrics (I got a rabbit who likes to hop / I got a girl and she likes to shop / The other foot looks like it won't drop / I had an uncle and he got shot). Very Beatles-esque. <br /> <br />5. Together - A great ballad with Brendan and Jack trading off vocals. The lyrics are decent, if not a bit cliched at times, and everyone sounds in top form. <br /> <br />6. Level - I dare anyone to listen to this and even TRY not to rock out. An insanely catchy keyboard beat with burning guitars. The solos between Jack and Brendan are, for lack of a better word, awesome. The vocals, once again, sound great! <br /> <br />7. Store Bought Bones - This one really catches your ear. Patrick's drum beat, which changes throughout the whole song, is insanely infectious. It's one of his finest moments on the whole disc. The harmonizing is almost haunting in a way, but they are great. Everybody gets a chance to solo at the end, a great way to end a great song. <br /> <br />8. Yellow Sun - It's hard not to bob your head to this bright, sunny song (no pun intended). This is also very Beatles sounding, if not as much as Intimate Secretary. The whole song has a nice feel to it, and it will instantly put you in a good mood. <br /> <br />9. Call It A Day - Another good ballad from Brendan. I really like the lyrics in this one, and Brendan's voice is really nice. The background vocals sound a bit colorless at first, but you kindof get used to them, and they don't sound so bad after a while. The song is also a bit repetitive, but it doesn't take too much away. Overall, maybe the weakest song on the disc, but still a very worthy one and not one to skip over. <br /> <br />10. Blue Veins - One of the best blues songs written in a while. Jack's voice sounds in top form here, and there's a pretty cool backwards section in the middle (although I personally prefer the solos they do in concert). A good way to end the album. <br /> <br />I was just blown away by this album. I've listened to it about 10 times in the past 2 days, and I love it every time. This isn't just a silly side project by any means. The Raconteurs take themselves seriously in their music, and it shows. If this is what we have to hold us over while we wait for the next Stripes album, I won't be complaining for a minute. Don't miss this.
B000001DYD|5.0|RID OF ME was PJ Harvey's sophomore effort and hands down, my favorite album of all time.  Truly!  I wish I could convey just how excellent this album is and how much it's changed my life but alas, words can never describe the experience of the wave of emotion and longing this album will hit you with.  Even now, over a decade later, my heart still skips a beat whenever I anticipate hearing this CD.  It is that good.<br /><br />A lot of people describe this album as raw, noisy, angry and uncompromising.  And while that may be true enough, I think it is also profound, deeply passionate and to me, storytelling at its best.  The songwriting is superb, with topics we can all relate to, ranging from unrequited love to religious references to feminism to (attempted, anyway) murder.  Throw in Steve Albini's signature raw, stripped-to-the-core touch and we have this flawless of a record.  All the songs flow beautifully together, yet each song can hold its own.  I'm tempted to go through every song because honestly the whole album is fantastic but that would mean a review ten pages long and I know no one wants that, so I'm just gonna highlight a few songs that are extra special to me.<br /><br />The album kicks off with the song \\"Rid of Me\\" and what a great title track this is.  Starts off slow with a bit of guitar but by the end, it'll have you screaming from the top of your lungs, \\"Don't you wish you, NEVER, NEVER MET HER?!!\\"  This song is about a love affair gone sour and a desperate woman pleading and plotting for her lover to return but to no avail.<br /><br />\\"Missed\\" is such a beautiful, melodic, sorta downtempo song.  One cannot help but be moved by this song.  It is somewhat out of place on this album, I think, just like \\"Plants and Rags\\" seemed out of place on DRY.  Nevertheless, it's a great song.  PJ's vocals is especially effective here, lending to the lush, surreal vibe of the song and the lyrics are very heartfelt, supposedly about Mother Mary and how she went mad over her son's Crucifixion.<br /><br />\\"Legs\\" is awesome!  It is a jilted lover's anthem!  Such a wickedly intense song, from the opening crooning of, \\"OOOOOOhhhh, you're divinnnnne...\\" to the sinister last lines, \\"I might as well be dead.  But I could kill you instead.\\"  The lyrics are most powerful in this song, I think, with words like, \\"I'll bet you never thought I'd try.  Your mouth my love, was open wide... Got to ease my aching head.  Do you know, no other way, cut off your legs...\\"<br /><br />\\"Man-Size Sextet\\" is a two minute masterpiece of extra creepy strings and organs.  Think raised hair.<br /><br />\\"50ft Queenie\\" I call my therapeutic song.  It is one of my favorites to see live, with the mad high low beats merging with the crazy fast and fun lyrics.  I really feel a need to jump up and down and shout along with the words, \\"Hey now I'm the King of the world, you oughta hear my song.  You come and measure me, I'm twenty inches long!..\\"<br /><br />One of my favorite PJ Harvey songs is \\"Yuri-G.\\"  I cannot get enough of this lil' ditty!  \\"She's so white, she's so clean.  I'm telling you, she's everything.  I'd give it all, my sorry eyes, give just everything, she's got me so mesmerized..\\"  This song (I think) is about being envious of the moon and how exquisite it is, and pays homage to Yuri Gagarin, a Russian astronaut and the first man to orbit the earth.<br /><br />Ah, then we get to the most excellent of songs, \\"Man-Size.\\"  Oh Polly, thank you for gracing us with this amazing song.  I love to sing along with the lyrics because this song really help put things in perspective.  Told from a macho man's point of view, I can't help but get a sense of harrumph, well, a bit of penis envy, I suppose:<br /><br />\\"I'll measure time, I'll measure height<br /><br />I'll calculate my birth right<br /><br />Good Lord I'm big, I'm heading on<br /><br />Man-sized<br /><br />Got my leather boots on<br /><br />Got my girl, she is a WOW<br /><br />I cast my iron knickers down<br /><br />My babe looking cool and neat<br /><br />I'm pretty sure good enough to eat<br /><br />Man-sized, no need to shout<br /><br />Let it all, let it all hang out!<br /><br />I'm MAN SIZE! MAN SIZE! MAN SIZE!\\"<br /><br />The album ends with a few more great songs such as \\"Dry,\\" the excellent track \\"Me-Jane\\" and \\"Ecstasy.\\"  As I mentioned, there is not a bad song on this album, and depending on the day, I still discover bits about the record that's more brilliant than I remembered it to be.  I've just about worn out my copy, as I play it so often but yet somehow I never seem to tire of this CD.  And I doubt I ever will. B0007Y4TVU|4.0|Loved this album from the day it came out. I'm a huge System of a Down fan, and enjoy every one of their albums enormously. To me, they are one of the fastest, most precise bands out there with both personality and a real, genuine idea of melody.     For me, System of a Down keeps getting better. With each of their albums, there's been a crisper, cleaner production. Progressively, Tankian's vocals have faded just a bit to make room for guitarist Malakian's high pitched squeals. Guitars are more pronounced, as well as vocal choruses, and both the drums and bass have taken a backseat. Everything just sounds more systematic, exact, and coherent. Some people don't like this; I do.    Mesmerize is slicker than any of the band's previous albums. Lyrically, it succeeds mostly because it has a less direct expression of ideas than, say, Toxicity. While, I think, the album doesn't ever really reach a sense of lyric profundity (which I think System does now and then and I understand others would fight to the death on that), it also takes its tongue-in-cheek mentality to an even higher level, abandoning most forms of seriousness for an almost circus-like energy and grotesque theatricality. The worst lyrics System has ever wrote have been either based in trite, all-too-obvious political/world criticism, or lame, Eastern-inspired duality/psychology/whatever you want to call it. Not that Mesmerize doesn't say anything -- because it does -- but it seems equally as confident, with something that doesn't betray it's own confidence out of stupidity.    Oh yeah, this is a pop album. Can't name a catchier disc of 2005. It's hard, too; I don't understand those who claim that System's older stuff was \\"SO MUCH HARDER WTF!!!!!!\\". This is poppier than \\"Steal this Album\\" but just as tough, and \\"Toxicity\\" for me seems like it had the smallest balls of the bunch, but that was probably due to a muted production. Their debut album is the only one that qualifies as harder to me because it's both raw and loud.    Anyway I've written so much that I've bored myself. This is a great album with brilliant highs (BYOB, Question!) and a few average lows (Sad Statue, Old School Hollywood)... Wow what a pathetic conclusion.

B000ESST6U|5.0|First performed 20 February 1724 and frequently revived thereafter during Handel's lifetime, Giulio Cesare, like all of his operas, fell into obscurity for 2 centuries. Supposedly, they were uninteresting to a modern audience and unperformable by modern performers. Recent scholarship proved the absurdity of this mistaken viewpoint. Handel's operas are joining his oratorios in the repertory with Cesare probably most performed along with Serse.<br /><br />Cleopatra made a star of Beverly Sills. I think it may do the same for the uncommonly beautiful Danielle de Niese whose stunning appearance and rich soprano fill the Glyndebourne stage with that ineffable quality called 'starpower'. Glyndebourne and Opus Arte must agree because they showcase Ms. de Niece in a 30 minute documentary on disc 1 called 'Danielle de Niece and the Glyndebourne experience'! In it, appealing to the under 30 audience is explicitly discussed. Every aspect of this staging of Cesare is created with that mission in mind. Another documentary film included in the set is 'Entertainment is not a dirty word'. If you can deal with all this, you will enjoy this 3 disc DVD immensely. I found this performance funny, entertaining, inventive, a little glitzy (in a good way) and well sung. On the negative side, I found it slightly weaker dramatically but with some absorbing tragic singing from Angelika Kirschlager as Sesto and Patricia Bardon as Sesto's mother Cornelia. Sarah Connolly makes a fine Cesare. Christopher Maltman is a standout Achilla. The cast is quite good and they appear to be enjoying themselves. In a 4 hour opera that is probably helpful.<br /><br />William Christie is a superb conductor of Baroque opera. He has been joining his talents to productions that emphasize a more modern sensibilty. Some purists wonder where the real heart of Baroque opera is when singers cavort onstage in slinky Flapper dresses and designer sunglasses. I can live with it if the music is well performed: as it is here by the superb Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment. But even open-minded laissez-faire opera fans (like me) would like to see a real Baroque opera performed as written one day. This is a vastly entertaining production. The costumes are beautiful. The stagecraft and sets are brilliantly conceived. There is a wonderful wave machine with 19th Century ships-of-war at the rear of a Baroque-style stage. A harvest moon with stars glimmers in the sky. It is quite lovely. And the music by Handel is pretty good, too.<br /><br />This 3 DVD set is NTSC all regions shot in 16/9 true anamorphic widescreen in high definition. It looks beautiful. Sound is recorded in LPCM stereo and 5.1 DTS Digital Surround Sound. Both are crystal clear with DTS providing terrific immediacy and presence to the sound. You feel like you're there. Subtitles are in English, French, German, Spanish and Italian. Menus are in English. There are numerous extras: including the films mentioned, an illustrated plot synopsis, a cast gallery, production and rehearsal photos. The 48 page enclosed booklet is glossy, beautiful and informative. Total running time of the DVDs is 305 minutes. Another superb Opus Arte release.<br /><br />This is a wonderfully entertaining modern production with a great Baroque opera at its heart. If you can deal with the anachronisms and glitz, you will love it. If you're a purist, be forewarned. Strongly recommended.<br /><br />Mike Birmanrchestra of the Age of Enlightenment. But even open-minded laissez-faire opera fans (like me) would like to see a real Baroque opera performed as written one day. This is a vastly entertaining production. The costumes are beautiful. The stagecraft and sets are brilliantly conceived. There is a wonderful wave machine with 19th Century ships-of-war at the rear of a Baroque-style stage. A harvest moon with stars glimmers in the sky. It is quite lovely. And the music by Handel is pretty good, too.    This 3 DVD set is NTSC all regions shot in 16/9 true anamorphic widescreen in high definition. It looks beautiful. Sound is recorded in LPCM stereo and 5.1 DTS Digital Surround Sound. Both are crystal clear with DTS providing terrific immediacy and presence to the sound. You feel like you're there. Subtitles are in English, French, German, Spanish and Italian. Menus are in English. There are numerous extras: including the films mentioned, an illustrated plot synopsis, a cast gallery, production and rehearsal photos. The 48 page enclosed booklet is glossy, beautiful and informative. Total running time of the DVDs is 305 minutes. Another superb Opus Arte release.    This is a wonderfully entertaining modern production with a great Baroque opera at its heart. If you can deal with the anachronisms and glitz, you will love it. If you're a purist, be forewarned. Strongly recommended.    Mike Birman

0375831002|5.0|As an English teacher, I read at least 100 novels a year. The Book Thief ranks among the top ten I have read in the past ten years.  The prose style is marvelously creative, so completely captivating that word by word, moment by moment, the story is nearly impossible to stop reading.  Each and every character becomes real, but most memorable may be the father, Hans, whose kindness and courage are inseparable.  The voice of Death, the narrator, is different from any other voice that I have heard speaking of the horrors of WWII. In the midst of tragedy, compassion remains, even in the most unexpected places.  The publisher should be marketing The Book Thief as fiction for general readers (rather than \\"young adults\\")because it deserves the widest possible audience.

0452282152|3.0|<br /> Girl With a Pearl Earring by Tracy Chevalier is an enjoyable and thoughtful read.  It transfers the reader into the Delft, Holland in the mid-1600s via the eyes of a young servant girl.  Pre-knowledge of the setting is not a requirement of the reader as Chevalier does a magnificent job of flawlessly explaining the setting and place with interest and history versus story transfers unnoticeably.  The story is rich with the culture without any dullness.  How does Chevalier do it?  The narration is through Griet, a reserved servant girl sold to work in the great master artist, Vermeer's home -- she is to clean his studio.  As Griet explores her new residence, unravels mysteries of the elusive artist and learns how to interact with the fragile household the reader is slowly unfolded to her new settings and the place generally.  It is written with contemporary English in a way that is formal yet simplistic and does not clash with the setting.  The setting is often serene and Griet's insightful, reserved conscience is quick, enjoyable and realistic. <br /> <br /> As I fell deeper and deeper into the story, I quickly empathized with the various characters and their reserved yet tense relationships with one another.  The tensions are of interest and do not make the reader weary.  Then the novel turns and Griet becomes closer to the artist, more knowledgeable of the family and beings a romance of her own.  These great folds of the story are beautifully written escapes rich with painting, emotion and swiftly moving plot. <br /> <br /> I highly enjoyed the novel.  When the last page had turned, I wished to visit the town again, the fish markets, the studio, the brick roads and interesting characters.  The novel isn't complicated, it is written artistically and well but does not exceed a high scholastic level.  I believe young adults as early as junior high could fully appreciate and understand the novel.  However, the novel could easily peak the interest any age beyondit.  It is not wholly feminine, in fact, I think for Vermeer's character insight may be lost in women.  I would recommend the book on the basis of its story, enchantment and interest.

0393327655|2.0|I can't really review the whole book as I couldn't get beyond the first few pages before I had to put this book down, since its assumptions and initial arguments seemed fundamentally flawed.  But for the bits I read here goes.  <br /> <br />The book starts with the example of a young Muslim man blowing himself up on a bus in Israel and killing many others.  This is used to illustrate the madness of religion which Sam Harris seems to blame for many if not most or all of the world's ills.  He then twists uncomfortably as he tries to argue that the Tamil Tigers, who have killed hundreds of civilians in bomb attacks in Sri Lanka are motivated signifcantly by religion following, or being significantly influenced by Hinduism.  To me it would seem more consistent and truthful to say that these 'terrorist acts' are committed in pursuit of political goals. [notably, with reference to his probably largely American audience, he does not mention American bombings in Vietnam and napalming of civilians, or various other acts of terror committed by US administrations - these quoted American military acts being committed for imperialist, economic or other reasons - but surely not for religious reasons]  .  In my view there are clearly many reasons and influencing factors which result in people committing these types of violent acts, including perhaps deeper psychological factors which can find expression through religion but which are not religion itself.    <br /> <br />While I am a committed humanist, I cannot accept, as Sam Harris appears to claim,  that organised religion is responsible for all or most of the bad things happening in the world.   <br /> <br />Sam Harris's attempts to then attack religious moderates, with all the decency and courage these people bring to life, whatever their personal beliefs with respect to their God or Gods, is another error as far as I am concerned.   People who do good, encourage tolerance, love and understanding are to be lauded. I do not accept their beliefs but I would feel that in the scheme of things they are doing a whole lot more good than those who preach intolerance and hatred. <br /> <br />With such a bad beginning to this book I could go no further.  People who feel hatred for religion, who have been oppressed by religion and those who are looking for their views to be confirmed may enjoy this book.  But, as I've found with a number of other books of this type, focused analysis leads to identification of threadbare arguments and poorly supported hypotheses.  However although this book may lack scholarship, it does, through its subject matter, highlight real dangers from religious fundamentalists.  The established church was responsible for the massacres of the crusades, the inquisition, burning of witches, and much much more, holding back the advancement of science, reason and the search for knowledge  The most horrendous, barbarous  practices are carried out in countries following Islamic Sharia law. I have no time for such insitutions and practices.  But the idea that organised religion is responsible for all or even most of the bad events in the world seems far from the truth and if there was an argument that religion is so responsible, this book in my view, doesn't present it.  <br />    <br /> <br /> <br /> <br />

B000E33VWW|4.0|This was a very smartly made movie.  To understand Capote you must understand the man, and as you watch this movie you really understand the many layers of Truman Capote.  An egotist, that struggles with constant hints at homosexuality, as well as an insane genius.<br /><br />The basic plot of of the movie is that after great success from his novel \\"Breakfast at Tiffany's\\" he is onto his next great venture.  In 1959 a family was brutally murdered by close range shotgun in a very bloody massacre.  Truman Capote interviews and empathizes one of the murders to see the man under the crime.  In doing so, he creates one of the greatest non-fiction novels to date, \\"In Cold Blood.\\"  This movie uses great characterization and you really begin to understand what motivates each character in the story.<br /><br />This movie also used a lot of research, even little things like clearing up the rumor that Harper Lee wasn't the true author of \\"To Kill A Mockingbird\\" which wasn't even proven false until after the movie was on DVD, and many of his letters and conversations.  I found this movie very enjoyable, and Hoffman's best acted film to date.  It's much different than a lot of other roles he's done.<br /><br />For those who saw many of the other Oscar nominated movies like Munich, Crash, and Brokeback Mountain, I feel it is time for you to also give this movie a shot.  You won't be disappointed. This is definately worth purchasing, or at least seeing.

B00003ETOW|3.0|The reason for the atrocious quality of the DVDs and tapes is probably that they were made off old film prints from TV stations and the European theatrical release, with all their splices, dirt, color shifts, sound drop-outs, etc.  Not to mention old transfers to video from God knows when.  Maybe it's no longer copyright protected and in the public domain, so anyone with an old print can knock off some cheap copies and sell them at dollar stores and the like.<br /><br />Someone on an IMDB post says that the original material (e.g. the original negative, sound elements, copies used to make release prints and so on) was destroyed. If this is true, there is no way to get a re-mastered version as all you can do is try to find the best of these crappy broken-down prints and old video transfers.  Storing original negatives properly at a lab or other archival facility is expensive and it seems many producers just threw stuff away not thinking it would be worth anything in the future.  This is too bad as it sounds like it's a rather decent production that had some nice cinematography and good performances.
B000EGCZQC|5.0|This mini-lp sleeve version of this brilliant classic rock masterpiece is a real treat for fans.  It comes in a wonderfully designed gatefold sleeve which includes a sticker of an abstract from an old Time Magazine review of the album, all the lyrics in both English and Japanese and a poster of the band albeit in black and white.  The packaging so faithfully reproduces the original vinyl sleeve even down to the inner sleeve.<br /><br />The sound quality is an improvement over the previous remastered version however for the two big tracks, \\"Black Magic Woman\\" and \\"Oye Como Va\\" for some reason the bass overpowers everything else and even sounds muddy.  The rest of the tracks, including the bonus live ones, sound much better but it's a shame that for my 2 favourite hits, the sound engineer had to screw up the sound levels.<br /><br />And now to the quality of the songs: Carlos Santana who once played with Miles Davis is very obviously heavily influenced by him, Tito Puente and Gabor Szabo (Gypsy Queen) and this is very evident on this album. Peter Green from the original Fleetwood Mac and the composer of \\"Black Magic Woman\\" was also involved in the making of this cover version of his song which is arguably even better than the original which may not be the case for the other cover \\"Oye Como Va\\" wherein Tito Puente's version with lots more percussion probably is better and yet both tracks are every upcoming guitarist's dream jam songs.<br /><br />Speaking as a guitarist myself I can tell you that there are few joys that surpass that of jamming to \\"Oye Como Va\\" with a band and \\"Black Magic Woman\\" is one of the first songs that I learnt to play note-for-note when I first started playing years ago. Although most people remember the album for these 2 tracks, the rest of the tracks are also very good and \\"Samba Pa Ti\\" is just a brilliant piece of mood music and great tone and phrasing on the part of Carlos on guitar.<br /><br />Recommended.

I know that many people have knocked the character development and the uninspired dialogue, but I think that they miss the point of the film.  When you watch this film, I would encourage you not to build up any false expectations.  Instead, realize that the show you are about to view was made with great special effects and will feature numerous escapes \\"just in the knick of time\\" (Even if most are out of the realm of realism).  This is not an academy award nominee for best picture, but that doens't mean that it isn't a lot of fun to watch. <br /> <br />While the characters aren't developed very fully, most have a lot of charisma.  Josh Lucas, Kurt Russell, and Richard Dreyfus really stand out, but the rest do well, too.  The nature of the film, in which we're never sure who's going to live or die, makes the many close excapes exiting.  In fact, several of the stars die in the process, so you never really know who is going to make it.  Thus, even though we all know that some will escape, we never know until the end which ones that will be. <br /> <br />I also appreciate the fact that the film is only 1 1/2 hours long.  For an action film like this, that's about the limit before the viewer tires of all the effects and close calls.   <br /> <br />All in all, this film is one that most people can enjoy without having to think too hard.  While there is no sex in the film, the scenes of people dying are often disturbing, so the film is not for the very young.  Otherwise, I would recommend this to most people.

B0000DBJDM|5.0|One of the strangest \\"Live Music\\" DVD's I've ever seen, Pink Floyd: Live at Pompeii features a Pre-Dark Side of the Moon Pink Floyd rocking out in the ruins of Pompeii, Italy and giving their interviews. I want to see the band...Anyway, another cool thing about the show is that the performance stuff isn't even the best part. 1400062071|5.0|Elizabeth Strout's latest, \\"Abide With Me\\" is a wonderfully rich and satisfying novel. I agree with all the other 5-star reviews. I also wanted to point out how well Strout incorporates the Cold War era into her small town sensibilities. Little things, such as the way Tyler begins his sentences with \\"Say...\\" and how characters use \\"Godfree\\" rather than \\"God\\" to punctuate their outbursts, and that several families have invested in bomb shelters, all add so much to the overall authenticity and \\"feel\\" of the novel in time and place that you can really be transported to this provincial town in the late 1950s.<br /><br />In addition, the foggy specter of possible incest in Tyler's late wife's life is skimmed over in just the way it would have been in the 1950s.  Strout is wonderfully subtle! I'll look forward to her next novel - may it come soon!

1400079276|5.0|This is not an easy read. All of its 600 odd pages are littered with subtle undercurrents making it dense, complex and surreal at times. Often sad and wistful with copious amounts of philosophy, art and music thrown in, Kafka on the shore is never boring. True, parts of it are slower and some parts whizz by. Sometimes you'll feel frustrated at not getting what the author intends to tell you immediately. This book requires some patience. Its not fast food meant to be gobbled up in a quick bite. rather, it is like rare wine meant to be savored. <br /> <br />This is the first Murakami book I have read, so I may be off key in his writing styles and his previous works comparison. I will not reveal the plot, but let you in on the fact that often there isn't one. The author leaves a lot for you to decide in what you want to believe in... 'Everything is a metaphor' he writes and indeed its for you to decide how to decode it. Which is why you'll often find that you can relate to it at different levels. Its a sheer piece of art and you'll either love it or really hate it. <br /> <br />The journey of a 15 year old to clear his warped mind of a curse is intersected with that of 60 year old whose mind is much that of a young adult - unable to read or write. In that sense, the work is allegorical. What one lacks and searches, the other has - opening doorways to age and mind. Alternate chapters detail this journey and their paths cross though they may or may not ever meet physically. Murakami strongly uses the idea of a labrynth and the notion that we are the products of the reality of our minds. <br /> <br />One of the reviewers here remarked that he wasn't sure if Murakami is a Genius or merely someone really clever. I'm not sure myself - for very often you feel that something ordinary must have a hidden meaning in the book. Perhaps that is what the author means to deliver in the book. That our realities and our understandings of everything in this world is a product of who we really are. <br /> <br />A really fine piece of literature that deserves to be amongst the best books written recently.

B0009X766Y|5.0|Let's clear up this aspect ratio issue once and for all.  THE STING was shot in 1.37:1 for intended matting to 1.85:1 for theatrical exhibition.<br /><br />Many films are shot this way.<br /><br />When you watch a film shot through this process on television or full screen DVD, the matte is removed and you see more of the original negative image on the top and the bottom.  This often called \\"open matte\\".<br /><br />The latest release restores the theatrical exhibition ratio of 1.85:1.  In short, it replaces the intended matting.<br /><br />There's nothing \\"bogus\\" about the widescreen on the legacy release.  This is the way the movie was originally shown in theatres.

B0000262QW|4.0|Released prior to his more familiar synth-laden jazz fusion offerings, this vibrant recording features Corea exclusively utilizing the electric piano to produce a quietly joyful sound.  The title track starts quietly with soft e. piano cadences, joined by Airto Moreira's innovative percussion.  Flora Purim, at the peak of her vocal abilities, insinuates herself into the mix, using her elegant voice as an instrument, segueing into a Joe Farrell flute solo.  The song diminishes and slows back to a Corea solo, then speeds into an effective blend of keyboard chords and Stanley Clarke's melodic driving bass.<br /><br />\\"Crystal Silence\\" features Farrell's delicate soprano sax.  \\"What Game Shall We Play\\" features words by Corea's longtime lyricist Neville Potter, which are brightly sung by Purim with a decidedly upbeat Latin edge.  \\"Sometime Ago-LaFiesta\\" spotlights each member of this extremely gifted band as they start out in a wistful ballad moving into a musical rendering of a Spanish Festival.  Recorded in February, 1972 for ECM records, \\"Return to Forever\\" was produced by Manfred Eicher

8590379825|5.0|I am new to Lua. While a C++ developer, having used Perl, Python and Ruby, I was suprised by how much you can do with this compact scripting language.<br /><br />The second edition is as eloquently written as the first (which is available online), but with new material and even more examples. In little time it introduced me to all aspects of the latest version of Lua -- 5.1 -- which includes a number of new features such as the new package system. Being a newcomer, it was nice to have a recent book covering all aspects of this latest version.<br /><br />The book is well organized. It works as both a primer and complete course on the langauge. It covers the basic tenets and first principles, as well as the subtleties. It is written in the spirit of Lua: accomplishing much in minimal space. It does so through crisp, engaging writing and thorough, well-crafted examples. It is one of those books that feels timeless -- so well done that you mark your name on it with a Sharpie.<br /><br />Lua is both a language and developer's tool. Part IV of the book, devoted to the C API, is as thorough for developers as the preceding parts are for language users. As I am using Lua in a multi-threaded environment, the second edition had the perfect example covering everything I needed to know -- from managing multiple states (interpreters) to wrapping C/C++ data structures.<br /><br />I was so pleased with the book, I emailed the author. If you use Lua, and especially if you are new to Lua, you won't be disappointed with this edition.
